positions.title: Rationalist Foundationalism
positions.thesis: Knowledge rests on bedrock of non-empirical, purely logical truths
positions.development: WORK-005 provides detailed transcendental argument for a priori knowledge necessity

positions.title: Anti-Empiricism
positions.thesis: Strict empiricism false; non-empirical knowledge required for all knowledge
key_arguments: Rules of inference cannot themselves be learned empirically

positions.title: Knowledge as Non-Accidentally Justified True Belief
positions.thesis: Four conditions for knowledge: truth, belief, justification, non-accidental connection

positions.title: Philosophy Justifies Empirical Science's Presuppositions
positions.thesis: Empirical disciplines make assumptions they cannot empirically justify. Only philosophy can provide non-empirical justification. Philosophy is meta-science.
positions.consistency: New position compatible with EP-001 and EP-002

positions.title: Observation Cannot Self-Corroborate
positions.thesis: Observation cannot justify that observation is reliable. Witnesses cannot self-corroborate. Pure empiricism is circular.

positions.title: Aboriginal Procedural Knowledge
positions.thesis: Humans have in-built procedural knowledge of dependence-relations
positions.consistency: Compatible with WORK-005 a priori knowledge positions

positions.title: Continuity-Based External World Knowledge
positions.thesis: We know external world by interpolating continuities between experiential data

positions.title: Two Ways Sense-Perception Adds to Knowledge
positions.thesis: Perception contributes via (1) direct content transmission and (2) triggering ratiocinative processes beyond perceptual content

positions.title: Principles Cannot Be Sense-Perceived
positions.thesis: Can perceive specific objects but cannot perceive principles or general truths. Principles grasped through reason.

positions.title: Non-Empirical Knowledge Exists
positions.thesis: Some truths are known without empirical justification: mathematical, logical, some metaphysical

positions.title: All Non-Empirical Knowledge is Analytic
positions.thesis: All non-empirical knowledge concerns conceptual structures. Explicitly rejects Kant's synthetic a priori.

positions.title: A Priori Knowledge as Constitutive of Reasoning Ability
positions.thesis: A priori knowledge = knowledge constitutive of ability to reason. Not acquired through experience but enables learning from experience.

positions.title: A Priori Knowledge Necessary for Any Learning
positions.thesis: Cannot learn from experience without a priori knowledge. Cannot deduce principles of deduction from experience (circular). Must have deductive knowledge ab initio.

positions.title: A Priori Knowledge as Subpersonal
positions.thesis: A priori knowledge not ordinary propositional knowledge but constitutive of subject itself. Principles are ability to think, not objects of thought.

positions.title: Refutation of Humean Skepticism
positions.thesis: Induction justified; Hume's argument commits gambler's fallacy

positions.title: Gettier Problem: Justification Must Be Non-Accidental
positions.thesis: Justified true belief is not sufficient for knowledge. The connection between justification and truth must be non-accidental.

positions.title: Three Sources of Justification
positions.thesis: There are ultimately only three sources of justification: (a) perceptual evidence, (b) introspective evidence, (c) rational inference.

positions.title: Testimony Requires Independent Verification
positions.thesis: For testimony-based belief to constitute knowledge, one must have independent evidence of the source's reliability.

positions.title: Cartesian Skepticism Refuted
positions.thesis: Global skepticism is self-refuting. The skeptical hypothesis cannot coherently be entertained.

positions.title: Inductive Inference Cannot Be Justified A Posteriori
positions.thesis: The principle of induction cannot be justified empirically without circularity.

positions.title: Rationalist Solution to Induction
positions.thesis: The principle of induction must be known a priori if it is to be justified at all.

positions.title: Universals Cannot Be Sense-Perceived
positions.thesis: Universals cannot be sense-perceived because they are non-spatiotemporal and perception requires causal interaction.
positions.consistency: FOUNDATIONAL - key premise for refuting empiricism

positions.title: Thought Requires Universals
positions.thesis: All thought, language, and explanation require universals. The idea of non-universal-involving thought is incoherent.

positions.title: Empiricism Refuted by Need for Universals
positions.thesis: Strict empiricism is false. Since universals are required for all thought and cannot be sense-perceived, not all knowledge is empirical.
positions.consistency: CENTRAL ARGUMENT - synthesizes EP-022, EP-023, META-004

positions.title: Berkeley's 'To Be Is To Be Perceived' Refuted
positions.thesis: Berkeley's idealism is false. Multiple arguments refute 'esse est percipi'.

positions.title: Phenomenalism Refuted
positions.thesis: Phenomenalism (reducing physical objects to perceptions) is false. Carnap's project failed.

positions.title: Poverty of Stimulus Argument for A Priori Knowledge (Chomsky)
positions.thesis: Humans acquire linguistic competence from minimal data while non-linguistic entities cannot, proving humans possess innate, pre-experiential cognitive structure (a priori knowledge).
positions.consistency: FOUNDATIONAL - provides empirical evidence for EP-001, EP-002, EP-010-015
positions.significance: Bridges cognitive science and philosophical rationalism

positions.title: Innate Cognitive Structure Required for Language Learning
positions.thesis: Language acquisition requires pre-existing innate cognitive structure. This structure is cognitive, not merely physiological.

positions.title: Language Learning as 'Triggering' Pre-Existing Structure
positions.thesis: Experience does not create linguistic knowledge de novo but 'triggers' or 'turns on' pre-existing cognitive structures. Learning is activation, not construction.

positions.title: A Priori Knowledge as Cognitive Framework (Not Framework Content)
positions.thesis: A priori knowledge is not knowledge you have (content within framework) but knowledge you are (the framework itself). It is not the object of awareness but the subject that makes awareness possible.
positions.significance: Critical distinction for understanding rationalism properly
positions.key_insight: Framework cannot observe itself as an object

positions.title: Framework-Knowledge vs Content-Knowledge Distinction
positions.thesis: Fundamental distinction between (1) structure-internal knowledge (learned, content) and (2) structure-constitutive knowledge (a priori, framework). All learned knowledge presupposes the framework.

positions.title: Deep Unconsciousness of Cognitive Framework
positions.thesis: Framework-constitutive structures are 'deeply unconscious' (Chomsky's term) - unlike Freudian unconscious. Cannot become conscious because consciousness presupposes them.
positions.distinction: Freudian unconscious = hidden contents; Chomskyan deep unconscious = structural conditions

positions.title: Causation as Continuity Not Regularity
positions.thesis: For x to cause y is for y to be a continuation of x, not for x-like events to always precede y-like events. Knowledge of the future is based on continuities, not regularities.
positions.explanation: This resolves Hume's problem of induction by reconceptualizing causation. Regularities are epistemically useful because they indicate where to look for continuities, but only knowledge of continuities can ground legitimate inferences about the future. Discontinuity represents ex nihilo change, whereas continuity represents preservation, and the legitimacy of causal inference lies in the irrationality of positing spontaneities.
key_consequences: Enumerative induction is either non-existent or illegitimate
We can know that x caused y even without knowledge of other cases of x-like events followed by y-like events
Knowledge of continuities can exist without knowledge of repetitions
Solves Goodman's New Riddle of Induction (makes it a non-riddle)

positions.title: Knowledge Without Known Justification
positions.thesis: A belief must be justified to constitute knowledge, but it is not necessary that one know that justification. Knowledge starts with beliefs that are not themselves knowledge but are justified.
positions.explanation: This resolves the infinite regress problem in epistemology. A belief can be useful and therefore retained because it is consistent with data and therefore justified, without its owner knowing what that justification is. Only justified beliefs are knowledge-constitutive, but there is no regress because a belief can be justified without its owner knowing the justification.
key_implications: Justification is objective (belief can be justified even if subject doesn't know how)
Infinite regress objection to foundationalism is blocked

positions.title: Knowledge-Seeking as Description Satisfaction
positions.thesis: Seeking knowledge involves knowing of a description that it is uniquely instantiated but not knowing what that instance is. Finding knowledge involves learning of some object that it satisfies that description.
positions.explanation: This resolves the Socratic paradox about how learning is possible. When searching for information, one knows a uniquely instantiating description but not what instantiates it. Finding the information means learning which object satisfies the description. One can seek without already possessing, contrary to the paradox.

positions.title: Learning Presupposes Constitutive Knowledge
positions.thesis: The ability to learn presupposes knowledge of a kind, but such knowledge is constitutive of one's mind and therefore isn't acquired. All acquired knowledge is learned, but not all knowledge is acquired.
positions.explanation: This distinguishes between constitutive and acquired knowledge, resolving the paradox that one cannot have knowledge without acquiring it (since all knowledge is learned), yet cannot acquire it without having it (since a mind devoid of knowledge is no mind at all). Some knowledge is constitutive of mentality itself.
key_implications: Supports nativism/rationalism about certain forms of knowledge
Vindicates Chomsky's arguments about language acquisition
Explains how learning is possible without circularity

positions.title: Experiential Learning Hierarchy
positions.thesis: Learning proceeds through stages of increasing retention and depth: 'I forget what I hear. I remember what I see. I learn what I do.' Active doing produces the deepest learning.
positions.explanation: This articulates a hierarchy of learning methods: passive auditory (forget), visual (remember), kinesthetic/experiential (learn). It prioritizes active engagement and practice over passive reception.
positions.epistemic_principle: Learning requires active participation; mere exposure is insufficient
positions.relates_to: Contemporary learning theory about active learning

positions.title: Wisdom from Bitter Experience
positions.thesis: All wisdom is based on experience, specifically bitter experience. Wisdom involves turning darkness into light - extracting positive lessons from negative experiences.
positions.explanation: When asked if wisdom comes from experience or pure intellect, the Master responds: 'All wisdom is based on experience. Bitter experience. And lots of it.' The dark experiences themselves are not wisdom; wisdom is what they bequeath - the transformation of darkness into light.
positions.philosophical_implication: Empiricist epistemology about practical wisdom; suffering as pedagogical
positions.contrasts_with: Pure rationalist views that wisdom derives from intellect alone

positions.title: Induction as Explanatory Not Enumerative
positions.thesis: Induction is inherently explanatory rather than purely enumerative. Successful inductive inference requires integrating statistical data with implicit theoretical frameworks concerning causation, continuity, and natural kinds. Pure enumerative induction is fundamentally inadequate.
positions.ai_evidence: AI systems incorporate feature correlation/causal networks, temporal/contextual stability, natural kind recognition, hierarchical pattern recognition—pure enumeration fails
positions.goodman_solution: AI solves grue paradox by recognizing discontinuous color changes without cause are implausible

positions.title: Discovery Follows Logical Principles
positions.thesis: Scientific discovery follows identifiable logical principles that are truth-tracking rather than merely psychological. Discovery and justification are not categorically distinct but interrelated aspects of theoretical reasoning.
positions.falsifies: Popper's claim that discovery is purely psychological and lacks logic

positions.title: Reverse Brain Engineering as Philosophy of Science Method
positions.thesis: By building AI systems that successfully replicate scientific reasoning, we can reverse-engineer cognitive principles underlying scientific discovery, providing empirically-grounded philosophy of science.
positions.methodological_innovation: Use AI implementation as empirical test of philosophical theories

positions.title: AI Falsifies External World Skepticism
positions.thesis: AI systems' consistent success at tasks requiring external world knowledge (medical diagnosis, object tracking) demonstrates treating perceptions as causally connected to external reality leads to reliable knowledge. If external world skepticism were correct, such success would be miraculous.

positions.title: Knowledge of Unobservables is Routine
positions.thesis: Knowledge of unobservables is not only possible but routine when proper theoretical frameworks are in place. AI systems successfully infer unobservable entities from observable patterns.
positions.example: CERN AI systems identifying particle properties never directly observed

positions.title: Future Knowledge Through Causal Understanding
positions.thesis: Knowledge of future is possible through understanding causal mechanisms and continuities. AI weather prediction demonstrates this through increasing accuracy.

positions.title: Counterfactual Knowledge is Knowledge of Rule Systems
positions.thesis: Counterfactual knowledge is genuine knowledge of existing rule systems and their implications. AI systems like AlphaGo demonstrate this through successful counterfactual reasoning.

positions.title: No Knowledge is Purely Observational
positions.thesis: All knowledge requires integration of empirical and conceptual/theoretical components. Pure observation without conceptual frameworks is insufficient for understanding.
positions.examples: Language reference resolution, image recognition of obscured objects, medical diagnosis—all require theoretical frameworks

positions.title: Theoretical Understanding Requires Causation and Continuity
positions.thesis: Successful theoretical knowledge is based on understanding causal mechanisms and continuity. Statistical and theoretical components must be integrated—pure correlation is insufficient.
positions.evidence: Medical AI with disease mechanism understanding outperforms pure statistical approaches

positions.title: Gettier Problem Solution: Scalable Justification
positions.thesis: Knowledge requires more than justified true belief—it requires justification that serves as proper conduit between reality and belief. Gettier cases involve justification that isn't scalable: it may work in one case but fails systematically when applied broadly.
positions.ai_parallel: AI systems naturally evolve away from unreliable justificatory patterns producing Gettier-like situations toward robust knowledge representations

positions.title: Coherentist Knowledge Architecture in AI
positions.thesis: Neural architecture of AI systems supports coherentist rather than foundationalist theory of knowledge. Both human and artificial knowledge are best understood as interconnected webs rather than hierarchical structures built on foundations.
positions.ai_evidence: Neural networks develop knowledge through interconnected activation patterns, not foundational axioms

positions.title: AI Falsifies Enumerative Induction Model
source: WORK-011 (Essay 2: How AI Falsifies Enumerative Induction)
positions.thesis: AI systems demonstrate that successful induction does not proceed by enumerating instances and generalizing. Instead, AI uses pattern recognition, analogy, and constraint satisfaction that cannot be reduced to simple enumeration of cases.
positions.development: This falsifies a major traditional theory of induction. AI provides empirical evidence that induction works differently than philosophers thought - it's pattern recognition, not enumeration.

positions.title: Pattern Recognition as Alternative to Enumeration
positions.thesis: Successful inductive reasoning operates through pattern recognition mechanisms that identify structural similarities rather than counting instances. AI systems reveal this by succeeding at induction without explicit enumeration.
positions.development: This provides the positive alternative to enumerative induction - pattern recognition. AI shows how induction actually works.

positions.title: AI Resolves Rationalism vs Empiricism Debate
positions.thesis: AI systems demonstrate that knowledge acquisition requires both innate structure (rationalist element) and learning from data (empiricist element). Neither pure rationalism nor pure empiricism can account for AI's success. The debate is resolved by recognizing both are necessary.
positions.development: This resolves one of philosophy's oldest debates using AI as evidence. AI needs both innate architecture and learning from data, showing both rationalists and empiricists were partly right.

positions.title: Innate Architecture is Necessary for Learning
positions.thesis: AI systems require substantial innate architectural constraints to learn successfully from data. This vindicates the rationalist insight that some knowledge structure must precede experience, while acknowledging the empiricist insight that specific content comes from experience.
positions.development: This explains how AI resolves the debate - by showing that innate structure is necessary but not sufficient. You can't learn without prior structure, vindicating Kant and Chomsky.

positions.title: Knowledge Acquisition is Neither Pure Discovery nor Pure Construction
positions.thesis: AI reveals that knowledge acquisition is neither pure discovery of pre-existing facts (naive realism) nor pure construction from experience (radical constructivism). It involves interaction between innate processing architecture and environmental structure.
positions.development: This provides a middle ground between realism and constructivism. Knowledge involves both discovery and construction - it's interactive, not passive reception or arbitrary construction.

positions.title: AI Solves the Gettier Problem
positions.thesis: AI learning systems demonstrate a solution to the Gettier problem by showing that genuine knowledge requires not just justified true belief but also that the justification tracks truth through a reliable causal-computational process. AI systems that learn reliably exemplify this tracking relationship.
positions.development: This solves the Gettier problem that has plagued epistemology since 1963. AI shows that knowledge requires reliable process that tracks truth - a fourth condition beyond JTB.

positions.title: Reliable Process Theory of Knowledge via AI
positions.thesis: AI systems reveal that knowledge requires beliefs formed through reliable processes that systematically track truth. This vindicates reliabilist theories of knowledge over traditional JTB (justified true belief) accounts.
positions.development: This vindicates reliabilism (Goldman's theory) by showing that AI knowledge works through reliable processes. AI provides empirical support for a philosophical theory of knowledge.

positions.title: Knowledge Systems Minimize Anomalies
positions.thesis: Both human knowledge and AI systems operate by minimizing anomalies - discrepancies between expectations and observations. This convergence reveals anomaly minimization as a fundamental principle of rational cognition.
positions.development: This identifies a universal principle of cognition - anomaly minimization. Both humans and AI work this way, suggesting it's fundamental to rationality itself.

positions.title: AI Learning Mirrors Scientific Theory Revision
positions.thesis: The process by which AI systems update their models to accommodate new data mirrors the process of scientific theory revision in response to anomalies. This suggests a common underlying logic of belief revision.
positions.development: This draws a parallel between AI learning and scientific method. Both involve belief revision in response to anomalies, suggesting they share underlying rational principles.

positions.title: Continuous Properties Are Cognitively Necessary
positions.thesis: AI reveals that continuous (graded) properties are necessary for cognitive systems to handle uncertainty and partial information, but this doesn't entail that truth itself is non-binary. Epistemic gradations are compatible with metaphysical bivalence.
positions.development: This distinguishes epistemic from metaphysical questions about truth. Continuous confidence values are needed epistemically but truth itself remains binary - AI shows how both can be true.

positions.title: AI Vindicates Pragmatist Theory of Knowledge
positions.thesis: AI development vindicates pragmatism's core insight that knowledge acquisition is fundamentally interactive rather than passive. AI systems learn through active engagement with their environment, validating pragmatist emphasis on the practical, interactive nature of inquiry.
positions.development: This vindicates Dewey and James's pragmatism through AI. Knowledge is not passive reception but active interaction with reality - AI demonstrates this empirically.

positions.title: AI as New Epistemic Faculty
positions.thesis: Interaction with AI constitutes a genuinely new epistemic faculty - a fourth level of observation beyond passive observation, active interaction, and tool creation. AI enables rational interaction with our own capacity for rational interaction, generating unique knowledge.
positions.development: This is revolutionary - AI is not just another tool but a new epistemic faculty. It's second-order reflexive interaction with rationality itself, generating knowledge impossible to obtain otherwise.

positions.title: Knowledge is Inherently Perspectival and Interactive
positions.thesis: AI reveals that all knowledge, even 'objective' knowledge, begins from perspectival, interaction-based data driven by practical interests. There is no view from nowhere - even AI's knowledge is grounded in its interactions with reality.
positions.development: This challenges the idea of pure objective knowledge. All knowledge, including AI's, is grounded in interaction and perspective. This vindicates pragmatism against naive realism.

positions.title: Tool-Creating Interaction Generates Irreducible Knowledge
positions.thesis: Creating tools (including AI) generates knowledge that cannot be obtained from merely using tools or observing passively. Each level of reflexive interaction (tool use, tool creation, AI development) reveals new knowledge irreducible to lower levels.
positions.development: This articulates a hierarchy of epistemic levels. Tool creation gives knowledge impossible from tool use, and AI development (second-order tool creation) gives knowledge impossible from first-order creation.

positions.title: Two Kinds of Knowledge: Direct and Indirect
positions.thesis: There are exactly two kinds of knowledge: direct (non-inferential, primitive) knowledge and indirect (inferential) knowledge. All knowledge falls into one of these two categories.
positions.justification: This represents a fundamental epistemic distinction. Direct knowledge requires no inference from other beliefs, while indirect knowledge is derived through reasoning from other knowledge.
positions.theoretical_significance: Establishes the foundational binary taxonomy of knowledge types that structures epistemological inquiry

positions.title: All Theoretical Knowledge is Inferential
positions.thesis: All theoretical knowledge is inferential knowledge, though not all inferential knowledge is theoretical knowledge. Theoretical knowledge requires reasoning from observations to explanatory hypotheses.
positions.justification: Theoretical knowledge goes beyond direct observation to posit explanatory structures. It necessarily involves inference from observable data to theoretical entities or principles.
positions.theoretical_significance: Distinguishes theoretical knowledge from other forms of inferential knowledge, clarifying the nature of scientific theorizing

positions.title: Knowledge is Justified True Belief (But Not Vice Versa)
positions.thesis: All knowledge is justified true belief, but not all justified true belief is knowledge. Additional conditions beyond justification, truth, and belief are required for knowledge.
positions.justification: While knowledge requires justified true belief, Gettier-type cases show that these three conditions are insufficient. The work establishes information-transmission as the additional required condition.
positions.theoretical_significance: Acknowledges the Gettier problem while maintaining JTB as necessary (though insufficient) for knowledge

positions.title: Two Kinds of Dependence Relations: Causal and Logical
positions.thesis: There are exactly two fundamental types of dependence relations: causal dependence relations and logical dependence relations. These are distinct and irreducible to each other.
positions.justification: Causal relations involve temporal priority and compulsion between events. Logical relations involve necessity between propositions independent of temporal ordering.
positions.theoretical_significance: Establishes a fundamental metaphysical-epistemic distinction that structures understanding of both knowledge and reality

positions.title: Logical Dependence Relations Not Known Through Observation
positions.thesis: Relations of logical dependence are not known through observation. They are known a priori, through conceptual analysis or reasoning, not through empirical investigation.
positions.justification: Logical relations hold between propositions in virtue of their meanings and forms, not in virtue of empirical facts. Observation reveals causal relations but not logical relations.
positions.theoretical_significance: Establishes the a priori character of logic and distinguishes logical from empirical knowledge

positions.title: Causal Relations Known Through Observation
positions.thesis: Causal relations are known through observation. Unlike logical relations, causal dependencies are empirical matters discoverable through perception and experience.
positions.justification: Causation involves temporal sequences of events in the world. Such sequences are observable and form the empirical basis for causal knowledge.
positions.theoretical_significance: Establishes the empirical, a posteriori character of causal knowledge in contrast to logical knowledge

positions.title: Analytic Knowledge is Always Knowledge of Dependence Relations
positions.thesis: Analytic knowledge is always and necessarily knowledge of dependence-relations. To know analytic truths is to know how concepts or propositions depend on each other.
positions.justification: Analytic truths hold in virtue of meanings and logical relations. Such truths are knowable a priori because they concern relationships between concepts rather than empirical facts.
positions.theoretical_significance: Clarifies the nature of analytic knowledge as essentially relational and a priori

positions.title: Propositions Are the Objects of Belief
positions.thesis: Propositions, not objects or states of affairs, are the proper objects of belief. To believe is to take a proposition to be true.
positions.justification: Beliefs have truth-values, and only propositions have truth-values. Objects neither are nor fail to be true. Therefore beliefs must have propositions as their objects.
positions.theoretical_significance: Establishes the intentional structure of belief and its relationship to truth

positions.title: Knowledge Distinct From Awareness
positions.thesis: Knowledge must be sharply distinguished from mere awareness. One can be aware of something without knowing anything about it, and one can know things without being directly aware of them.
positions.justification: Awareness is direct acquaintance with objects or experiences. Knowledge involves propositional content and justified true belief. These are distinct cognitive states.
positions.theoretical_significance: Distinguishes propositional knowledge from acquaintance, resolving confusion between these distinct epistemic notions

positions.title: The Concept of Evidence: Causal Relatedness
positions.thesis: One state of affairs e is evidence of another state of affairs e* if and only if e and e* are causally related such that knowledge of e's existence provides reason to believe in e*'s existence.
positions.justification: Evidence requires a non-accidental connection between states of affairs. Only causal relations provide such connections that justify inferring from one state to another.
positions.theoretical_significance: Grounds evidential relations in causation, explaining why certain states of affairs support beliefs about others

positions.title: Information-Transmission as Structure-Preservation
positions.thesis: Information-transmission is structure-preservation. An information-bearing series is one in which earlier events transmit their structure to later events through causal processes that preserve structural relationships.
positions.justification: Information exists when structure is maintained across causal processes. When you speak on a phone, sound structures are encoded and decoded while preserving structural relationships.
positions.theoretical_significance: Provides a precise account of information in terms of structure-preservation, grounding information theory in metaphysics

positions.title: Information Distinct From Evidence
positions.thesis: All information is evidence, but not all evidence is information. Evidence requires only causal relatedness; information requires causal relatedness plus structure-preservation.
positions.justification: The elevator stopping is evidence that someone pushed the button (causal relation), but neither event bears information about the other (no structure-preservation due to different structures).
positions.theoretical_significance: Distinguishes two types of epistemic relations, clarifying when causal connections support stronger or weaker inferences

positions.title: Information-Transmission as the Basis of Knowledge
positions.thesis: Knowledge is based on information-transmission. Our sense-perceptions are isomorphs of the objects they represent, inheriting structure from their causes. Beliefs are knowledge only to the extent they are linked by information-transmissive series to corresponding realities.
positions.justification: Veridical perception occurs when perceptual experiences inherit structure from their objects. Knowledge requires such structure-preserving causal connections to reality.
positions.theoretical_significance: Provides a comprehensive reliabilist-causal theory of knowledge grounded in information theory

positions.title: Knowledge Independent of Statistical Reliability
positions.thesis: The difference between knowledge and mere belief is not statistical. A belief is knowledge if and only if it is the end-result of an information-transmissive series, regardless of the general reliability of the mechanism that produced it.
positions.justification: A belief from an unreliable clock is knowledge if that particular instance involved information-transmission. A belief from a reliable clock is not knowledge unless that particular instance involved information-transmission.
positions.theoretical_significance: Distinguishes token-reliabilism from type-reliabilism, emphasizing particular causal histories over general reliability

positions.title: Biological Impossibility of Extreme Relativist Beliefs
positions.statement: It is biologically impossible to actually believe extreme relativist or deconstructionist positions. No one is drawn to such positions because they believe them; they perpetrate fraud for reasons of convenience, ego, and hate.
positions.justification: The systematic dismantling of epistemic instruments and the spurning of the very idea of truth cannot be genuine beliefs since they would make coherent thought impossible. Those who espouse such positions must therefore be engaging in fraud rather than expressing sincere convictions.
positions.theoretical_significance: Provides biological/cognitive constraint on genuine belief; distinguishes performative intellectual positions from psychologically possible beliefs; grounds critique of relativism in cognitive science

positions.title: Parental Instincts as Embodied Knowledge
positions.statement: Knowledge of the importance of healthy early-life attachments for psychological health is embodied in parental instincts. Parents, especially mothers, are naturally inclined to bond with their children, particularly when they are young and vulnerable, indicating innate recognition of attachment's developmental significance.
positions.justification: The natural inclination of parents to form attachments with offspring, especially in early vulnerable periods, reflects evolutionary incorporation of knowledge about attachment's importance. This innate behavioral disposition embodies empirical knowledge.
positions.theoretical_significance: Identifies instinctive behavior as form of embodied knowledge; suggests evolutionary pressures can encode empirical truths in behavioral dispositions

positions.title: Sellars' Myth of the Given
positions.statement: According to Sellars, what makes a given bit of phenomenal content have particular representational content is the addition of background knowledge and contextualizing information. To think that phenomenal content has intrinsic representational content is to commit 'the myth of the given' - a spurious epistemic foundationalism.
positions.justification: The tie shop examples demonstrate that visual sensations do not by themselves determine color properties; only sensations plus background knowledge about environmental conditions are color-determinate. This generalizes to all perceivable properties.
positions.theoretical_significance: Establishes anti-foundationalist position that sensory experience requires epistemic context to have determinate content

positions.title: Sensations as Property-Indeterminate Without Background Knowledge
positions.statement: Visual sensations (and sensory qualia generally) are property-indeterminate by themselves. In non-standard perceptual conditions (e.g., unusual lighting in the tie shop, or wearing magnifying goggles), the same sensation could correspond to different objective properties. Background knowledge about conditions of perception is required to determine which property the sensation represents.
positions.justification: In the tie shop with unusual lighting, you cannot tell whether a tie is maroon or burgundy from visual sensation alone. You must learn the correspondence rule between sensations-in-those-conditions and actual colors by checking ties in normal lighting. Similarly, with variable magnification goggles, visual sensations are size- and distance-indeterminate until you learn the correspondence between goggled-sensations and actual object properties.
positions.theoretical_significance: Provides concrete thought experiments demonstrating indeterminacy of raw sensation; shows representational content requires epistemic supplementation

positions.title: Two Versions of Anti-Foundationalism
positions.statement: Sellars' attack on the myth of the given comes in two strengths. Weak version: it is not typically true that qualia by themselves constitute awareness (knowledge) of anything external - something extra is needed to make a quale epistemic. Strong version: it is not typically true that qualia by themselves constitute representations - something extra is needed to give them representational content. Both versions are correct.
positions.justification: The arguments from property-indeterminacy of sensations show that qualia require supplementation both to have determinate representational content (strong version) and to constitute knowledge (weak version). The tie shop and goggles examples support both claims.
positions.theoretical_significance: Distinguishes two levels at which foundationalism fails; establishes that both representational and epistemic content require context

positions.title: Intentionalism Commits the Myth of the Given
positions.statement: Intentionalism is a strong form of foundationalism guilty of the myth of the given in both its forms. Intentionalism holds that qualia by themselves have determinate representational content without needing background knowledge, and that background knowledge cannot affect their representational content. This makes qualia foundational, performing representational and epistemic roles in isolation from epistemic context - precisely the foundationalism Sellars refuted.
positions.justification: If qualia had fixed representational content ab initio (as intentionalism requires), background knowledge couldn't help endow them with content, since that would require representational indeterminacy. But the arguments show qualia are representationally indeterminate, requiring contextual supplementation. Therefore intentionalism is false or anti-foundationalism is false.
positions.theoretical_significance: Establishes intentionalism as incompatible with widely accepted anti-foundationalism; forces choice between intentionalism and Sellarsian epistemology

positions.title: Learning Correspondence Rules for Non-Standard Perceptual Conditions
positions.statement: When perceptual conditions are non-standard, subjects must learn correspondence rules mapping sensations-under-those-conditions to objective properties. This learning requires checking sensations against how things appear under standard conditions. Once internalized, these rules enable immediate perception of properties even under non-standard conditions.
positions.justification: In the tie shop, you must repeatedly check tie colors in normal lighting, then observe their appearance in shop lighting, building a correspondence rule. Eventually you can 'just see' what color ties are in the shop without checking outside. The same process applies to variable magnification goggles.
positions.theoretical_significance: Explains how background knowledge becomes incorporated into perceptual experience; shows epistemic mediation can become automatic without becoming unnecessary

positions.title: Kant's Synthetic A Priori is Really Hard Analytic
positions.statement: Kant's 'synthetic a priori' truths (like 7+5=12 and 'a straight line is the shortest distance between two points') are not actually synthetic but rather 'hard analytic' - they are analytic truths that are difficult to recognize as such, requiring cognitive effort rather than immediate apprehension.
positions.justification: 7+5=12 follows analytically from 1+1=2 and other analytic premises via analytic consequence (Arthur Pap's argument). For anything x, if 7+x ≠ 12, then x is ipso facto not 5. The concepts' structures guarantee truth. Kant's error stems from conflating psychological difficulty of recognition with logical/conceptual independence.
positions.theoretical_significance: Eliminates Kant's problematic category of synthetic a priori; shows all necessity is either empirical or conceptual, with no third category of representational necessity

positions.title: Easy Analytic Versus Hard Analytic Distinction
positions.statement: Analytic truths divide into 'easy analytic' and 'hard analytic.' Easy analytic truths (e.g., 'circles are round,' 'triangles have three sides') are such that grasping them suffices for knowing their truth - denying them involves psychological as well as logical incoherence. Hard analytic truths (e.g., 'a circle is a class of points equidistant from a given point in a plane') involve only logical incoherence when denied; a sane person could believe their negation without psychic fragmentation.
positions.justification: To think of something as a circle just is to think of it as round - denying this requires psychic double-think. But one can coherently (if wrongly) deny the equidistant-points definition without such fragmentation. Both are made true by concepts, but differ in cognitive accessibility.
positions.theoretical_significance: Distinguishes psychological from logical coherence; explains why some conceptual truths seem substantive while others seem trivial; grounds Kantian synthetic a priori in cognitive psychology rather than metaphysics

positions.title: A Priori as Epistemological, Not Logical Property
positions.statement: For Kant, a priority is a property of our knowledge of propositions, not of propositions themselves. A proposition is a priori not in virtue of intrinsic logical properties but in virtue of how one comes to know it. Consequently, a proposition could in principle be a priori for one creature and a posteriori for another.
positions.justification: Kant explicitly conceives a priority in psychological/epistemological rather than strictly logical terms. This relativization to knowers is essential to his system but problematic - it makes necessity dependent on contingent facts about cognitive architecture.
positions.theoretical_significance: Exposes relativity in Kant's epistemology; shows his categories depend on facts about human cognition rather than logic alone

positions.title: Ex Nihilo Events are Logically Impossible
positions.statement: There are no ex nihilo (uncaused) events. The spatio-temporal manifold would comprise ex nihilo events only if it comprised events not co-located with other events - only if it comprised events it didn't comprise. Propositions alleging uncaused events (e.g., 'the newspaper spontaneously combusted') are self-contradictory when properly understood.
positions.justification: Hume argued uncaused events are possible because propositions describing them aren't self-contradictory. But this presupposes digital space-time. Given that spatiotemporal location is itself causal, an event lacking causal relations to other events would lack spatiotemporal location, hence wouldn't be spatiotemporal event at all.
positions.theoretical_significance: Refutes central Humean argument; establishes principle of sufficient reason on logical rather than metaphysical grounds

positions.title: Induction Justified by Analog Data, Not Digital Propositions
positions.statement: Induction is justified by continuous, analog sensory data rather than by discrete digital propositions. The logical basis for induction is precisely what is lost in digitization involved in embodying knowledge in propositions like 'every swan I've seen is white.' We subtly misrepresent our grounds for inductive belief when we try to propositionalize (digitize) them.
positions.justification: Perceptual content doesn't decompose like propositional content. A perception of a swan isn't such that one part corresponds to 'swan,' another to 'white,' etc. The perception gives continuous state of affairs. Propositions are schematic models of perceptual data, like court transcripts compared to actual speech - much information is lost in digitization.
positions.theoretical_significance: Dissolves Humean problem of induction by showing Hume attacks proposition-models rather than actual sensory grounds; establishes epistemological significance of analog/digital distinction

positions.title: Propositions as Schematic Meta-Data, Not Data
positions.statement: Propositions like 'every swan I've ever seen is white' are not the data that motivate or legitimate inductive beliefs - they are meta-data. Describing such propositions as 'data' is like identifying a court's finding of guilty with actuality of guilt. We cannot work backwards from meta-data to data, just as we cannot recover subtle speech inflections from stenographer's transcript.
positions.justification: What is reported by propositional descriptions is not content of perception itself but judgment about that content. When you see a swan and say 'I see a swan; it is white; it is eating a fish,' your perception doesn't have corresponding breakdown. The data motivating inductive belief is embodied in analog representations giving continuous reality, not discrete propositions.
positions.theoretical_significance: Distinguishes perceptual from propositional content; shows Humean skepticism attacks wrong target by focusing on propositional formulations

positions.title: Digital-Analog Compatibility Distinction
positions.statement: We must distinguish digital-compatibility from analog-compatibility - what is permissible given propositions from what is permissible given the analog data those propositions schematically represent. Propositions 'the rock will sprout wings' and 'no stone has ever sprouted wings' are digitally compatible, but their analog correlates involve discontinuities and perforations of space-time manifold making them analog-incompatible.
positions.justification: Hume rightly said those propositions are compatible. But this says little about states of affairs or non-digital data they represent. When we consider actual analog perceptual data (not schematic propositional models), the discontinuities required for rocks sprouting wings become apparent. Counter-inductive scenarios involve coherent propositions but incoherent analog reality.
positions.theoretical_significance: Resolves apparent modal puzzles by distinguishing propositional from perceptual possibility; shows limits of purely conceptual analysis

positions.title: Goodman's Grue Problem Exposes Hume's Circularity
positions.statement: As Nelson Goodman showed, given any explanatorily useful property x, we can construct explanatorily useless property y (like 'grue' or 'plopper') such that x and y are indistinguishable from purely statistical viewpoint. This exposes circularity in Hume's reasoning: properties like 'copper' are not inductively innocent but already embody causal/inductive commitments.
positions.justification: To describe something as copper is already to make inductive and causal claims. Hume's arguments become tautologically false if stated in terms of ordinary properties, or vacuous if stated in terms of bent predicates. Moment you use inductively committed predicates, Hume's position involves self-contradiction; if you use inductively inert predicates, argument establishes only vacuity that inferentially inert expressions are inferentially inert.
positions.theoretical_significance: Demonstrates internal incoherence in Humean empiricism; shows predicates themselves carry modal commitments

positions.title: Phenomenal States Require Theoretical Context (Sellars)
positions.statement: Following Sellars' Empiricism and the Philosophy of Mind: purely phenomenal states are representationally and epistemically empty except in context of knowledge concerning conditions under which they are experienced. Relevant contextual information can be given only in inductively and theoretically committed terms.
positions.justification: To describe perceptual situation requires terms like 'oak table,' 'upright piano,' 'lamp missing lampshade' - all replete with predictive and theoretical content. If Hume's position on induction is stated in such terms, it becomes trivially false; if stated in purely phenomenal terms, it becomes triviality (if articulable at all) from which nothing follows about induction's efficacy.
positions.theoretical_significance: Applies Sellarsian anti-foundationalism to Humean skepticism; shows empirical description presupposes theoretical framework

positions.position: Religious sentiment cannot be understood in strictly medical terms; it cannot be deconstructed
Religious sentiment must be understood on its own terms
All empirical beliefs involve an element of faith - a 'will to believe'
Empirical beliefs are necessarily underdetermined by the data
Empirical beliefs, when justified, are justified by their consequences
Religious beliefs are justified by their consequences and are therefore justified in the same way as other empirical beliefs
All hypotheses, including quintessentially scientific ones, involve an initial leap of faith; their legitimacy is established by their consequences
A belief is rational if it benefits the person who has it
The rationality of belief is justified only by its consequences
Religious belief involves a leap of faith, but this leap often proves worth making
The trench-atheist is not really making a leap of faith because he is surrendering to a part of himself (his conscience), not to an external deity
The alcoholic is only making a 'leap of faith' relative to what his conscious mind knows, not what his mind as a whole knows; therefore he isn't really making a leap of faith
Only principled (not accidental) generalizations can be confirmed
When 'all x's are y's' is read as principled generalization, it has nomic/causal content and is not equivalent with 'all non-y's are non-x's'
'All ravens are black' (when principled) says that being a raven grounds or causes blackness
Knowledge of the future is based on continuities, not regularities
Regularities often tell us where to look for continuities, but knowledge of regularities never constitutes knowledge of continuities
Enumerative induction is either non-existent or illegitimate
When we make legitimate inferences about the future, it is on the basis of knowledge of continuities, not observation of repetitions
We may have knowledge of continuities without knowledge of repetitions; we can know x caused y even with no other cases of x-like events followed by y-like events
One often knows x causes y without knowing exactly how y is continuous with x, by knowing secondary continuities that require positing a continuity
Goodman's 'new riddle of induction' is a non-riddle, since it's continuities not concomitances that ground knowledge
Although a belief must be justified to be knowledge, it isn't necessary that one know that justification
Knowledge starts with beliefs that are not knowledge; if such a belief is useful (consistent with data, justified), its owner likely retains it
A belief can be justified without its owner knowing what that justification is; this blocks the epistemic regress
Looking for information involves knowing a description is uniquely instantiated but not knowing what instantiates it
Finding information involves learning of some object that it satisfies a description one already knows to be instantiated
The ability to learn presupposes knowledge of a kind, but such knowledge is constitutive of one's mind and therefore isn't acquired

positions.title: Platonism about Properties
positions.thesis: Properties exist as non-spatiotemporal entities distinct from instances

positions.title: Propositions as Sets of Properties
positions.thesis: Propositions are sets of properties; truth is instantiatedness

positions.title: Anti-Constructivism
positions.thesis: Constructivism self-refuting through reductio

positions.title: Properties as Non-Spatiotemporal Entities (Platonism)
positions.thesis: Properties exist as non-spatiotemporal entities. They are not identical with their instances.

positions.title: Uninstantiated Properties Exist
positions.thesis: Properties can exist even when nothing has them. The property of being a unicorn exists.

positions.title: Determinism vs Randomness vs Unpredictability
positions.thesis: Determinism, randomness, and predictability are distinct concepts that must not be conflated.

positions.title: Personal Identity Through Time
positions.thesis: Personal identity consists in psychological continuity, not bodily continuity.

positions.title: Causality as Counterfactual Dependence
positions.thesis: Event A causes event B iff: (1) both occur, and (2) had A not occurred, B would not have occurred.

positions.title: Bundle Theory of Personal Identity
positions.thesis: A person/self is class of all mental contents I-related to given mental content. Two mental contents belong to same person iff there is chain such that each link directly interacts with its neighbor. Direct interaction = no intervening physical events.
positions.technical_definition: I-relation: transitive closure of direct mental interaction
positions.significance: Precise, materialist-compatible bundle theory using interaction criterion

positions.title: Content-Bearing Processes Are Ipso Facto Mental
positions.thesis: If physical process non-derivatively bears representational/thematic content, it is ipso facto mental (whatever else it is). Content-bearing is sufficient (though not necessary) for mentality.
positions.significance: Allows materialism while maintaining mentality. Physical processes can be mental if content-bearing.
positions.consistency: Neural processes transmitting mental content are themselves mental

positions.title: Binary Truth Despite Continuous Representation
positions.thesis: AI systems demonstrate that truth remains fundamentally binary (true/false) even though cognitive systems represent information continuously. Continuous confidence values or fuzzy representations are epistemic features, not ontological features of truth itself.
positions.development: This defends bivalence against fuzzy logic and degrees of truth. AI uses continuous representations epistemically but truth itself is binary. The continuous values represent uncertainty, not degrees of truth.

positions.title: Causation as the Essence of Temporal Precedence
positions.thesis: For one event e to precede another event e* is for there to be a possible causal process beginning with e and ending with e*. Simultaneity is the absence of such a process.
positions.justification: Temporal relations are defined by causal possibility. Events are temporally ordered in virtue of causal structure, not vice versa.
positions.theoretical_significance: Reduces temporal ordering to causal structure, providing a causal theory of time

positions.title: Continuity as the Essence of Causation
positions.thesis: Effects are continuations of their causes. Causation essentially involves continuity - causal processes preserve structural relationships across temporal intervals without gaps.
positions.justification: When high-resolution information is transmitted (e.g., a face on a computer), multiple concurrent causal lines preserve their mutual relations. Continuity distinguishes causal from non-causal regularities.
positions.theoretical_significance: Identifies continuity as the metaphysical essence of causation, grounding causal necessity in structural preservation

positions.title: Causation a Relation Between Events, Not Objects
positions.thesis: Causation is fundamentally a relation between events, not between objects. Objects participate in causal relations only derivatively, in virtue of events involving those objects.
positions.justification: It is not the match-object but the match-striking event that causes the ignition event. Causal relata must be the kinds of things that occur or happen.
positions.theoretical_significance: Establishes events as the proper relata of causal relations, resolving ontological questions about causation

positions.title: Conditions Identical with Event-Patterns
positions.thesis: Conditions are identical with event-patterns. A condition is not a state but rather a pattern or type of event sequence that can be instantiated multiple times.
positions.justification: When we say 'under these conditions, X happens,' we refer to a pattern of events that, when instantiated, leads to X. Conditions are repeatable event-structures.
positions.theoretical_significance: Clarifies the ontological status of conditions in causal explanation

positions.title: So-Called Changes Typically Identical with Meta-Changes
positions.thesis: What are ordinarily called changes are typically meta-changes - changes in the rate, direction, or pattern of already-occurring changes rather than absolute transitions from rest to motion or vice versa.
positions.justification: Most observable changes are alterations in existing processes. Acceleration is a change in velocity, which is already a change in position. Pure origination or cessation is rare.
positions.theoretical_significance: Reveals the hierarchical structure of change and process in nature

positions.title: Threshold Effects and Psychological Overdetermination
positions.thesis: In psychology, causation often involves exceeding thresholds rather than simple sufficient conditions. An effect may require the confluence of multiple reasons, none sufficient alone but jointly sufficient once a threshold is exceeded.
positions.justification: As Freud showed, falling in love may require accumulation of multiple reasons, none sufficient alone. Once enough accumulate, the threshold is exceeded and the effect occurs.
positions.theoretical_significance: Recognizes non-linear causation in psychological phenomena

positions.title: Threshold Effects and the Analog-Digital Distinction
positions.thesis: Discontinuous changes tend to involve threshold effects; continuous changes do not. To the extent the world changes discontinuously it has digital structure; to the extent continuously, analog structure.
positions.justification: Circuit breakers don't respond until electricity overload exceeds a threshold, then switch states abruptly (digital). Analog clocks change continuously with time (analog).
positions.theoretical_significance: Connects threshold effects to fundamental metaphysical distinction between discrete and continuous change

positions.title: Causes as INUS-Conditions
positions.thesis: In most contexts, to say 'X caused Y' means 'X was an INUS condition for Y' - an Insufficient but Non-redundant part of an Unnecessary but Sufficient condition for Y's occurrence.
positions.justification: Flipping the switch causes the light to turn on, yet the switch-flip alone is insufficient (needs working bulb, electricity). But given the light turned on, the flip was non-redundant part of a sufficient condition.
positions.theoretical_significance: Provides precise analysis of ordinary causal claims as involving complex conditional structures, following Mackie

positions.title: Counterfactuals Hold in Virtue of Dependence-Relations
positions.thesis: All counterfactuals affirm the existence of instances of necessitation of some kind. Causal counterfactuals hold in virtue of causal dependence-relations; logical counterfactuals hold in virtue of logical dependence-relations.
positions.justification: 'If Kennedy hadn't been assassinated, US would have withdrawn from Vietnam' affirms Kennedy's assassination caused continued involvement. 'If Smith had over $10, he'd have over $5' affirms logical entailment.
positions.theoretical_significance: Unifies analysis of counterfactuals under dependence-relations while distinguishing causal from logical varieties

positions.title: David Lewis's Possible Worlds Analysis of Counterfactuals Rejected
positions.thesis: David Lewis's analysis of counterfactuals in terms of similar possible worlds is false. Events have deep causal roots such that changing one event requires either massive world-differences or changes to deterministic mechanisms.
positions.justification: If Kennedy's assassination doesn't occur in world w, either (a) w differs so much from our world Kennedy might not exist, or (b) w's deterministic mechanisms differ. Either way, early withdrawal isn't guaranteed.
positions.theoretical_significance: Rejects possible worlds semantics for counterfactuals in favor of actual-world causal structure

positions.title: Program-Causality Distinguished from Token-Causality
positions.thesis: Program-causality differs from token-causality. Sometimes the appropriate causal explanation cites a condition that guaranteed occurrence of token-causes rather than the token-causes themselves.
positions.justification: Boiling water caused vessel to crack not by specific particle-collisions c1...cn but by guaranteeing occurrence of such collisions. Even if those specific collisions hadn't occurred, others would have.
positions.theoretical_significance: Distinguishes levels of causal explanation, recognizing both program-level and implementation-level causes

positions.title: Causal Redundancy Defeats Counterfactual Analysis
positions.thesis: Where there is causal redundancy, causal truths cannot be converted into counterfactual truths. 'X caused Y' can be true even when 'if X hadn't occurred, Y wouldn't have occurred' is false.
positions.justification: The bird died because Smith shot it, yet if Smith hadn't shot it (in a pack of hunters), the bird would still have died (another hunter would have shot it).
positions.theoretical_significance: Shows counterfactual analysis of causation fails in cases of overdetermination or backup causes

positions.title: Necessary Truths Don't Describe the Empirical World
positions.statement: If proposition P is necessarily true, then P doesn't describe the empirical world in any way at all. P's being true in world W₁ doesn't distinguish W₁ from W₂ or any other possible world. A 'description' that fails to distinguish its object from other possible objects is no description at all.
positions.justification: Necessity means truth in all possible worlds. But to describe world W is to say something distinguishing W from other possibilities. Since necessary truths hold in all worlds, they distinguish none, hence describe none. This refutes Kant's claim that synthetic a priori truths describe necessary features of the empirical world.
positions.theoretical_significance: Provides modal argument against synthetic a priori; shows necessity and empirical description are incompatible

positions.title: Transcendental Deduction of World-Structure from Coherent Experience
positions.statement: There is a hard-analytic connection between 'there exist beings who have cognitive wherewithal to raise metaphysical questions' and propositions about world-structure: any two events are related in space or time; there are causal relations among states of affairs; objects are things in which properties inhere (not mere bundles); human beings are things in which perceptions inhere (not mere bundles).
positions.justification: Given only that we have coherent (if not always accurate) thoughts and representations, the world must satisfy certain minimal conditions. These 'transcendental' conditions are necessarily satisfied by any world containing entities with coherent ideation. The necessity is logical (hard-analytic), not merely psychological.
positions.theoretical_significance: Provides metaphysical foundation derived from epistemological facts; links possibility of thought to necessary world-structure

positions.position: To be at rest is to fail to move during a non-null interval; an object at a point during its motion is not at rest
Any finite number can be represented as sum of infinite series; any case of motion involves traversing infinitely many finite distances in finite time
Space-time regions do not themselves have places; they are constituents, not occupants, of space-time
For x to cause y is for y to be a continuation of x, not for x-like events to always precede y-like events
Continuity represents preservation; discontinuity represents ex nihilo change
The legitimacy of inference from cause to effect lies in the irrationality of positing spontaneities

positions.title: Anti-Language of Thought
positions.thesis: We do not think in language (natural or innate)

positions.title: Perspectival Theory of Feelings
positions.thesis: Feelings represent relationship to universe, inherently perspectival

positions.title: Systematicity of Mental Representation
positions.thesis: Cognitive success depends on systematic connection and coherence of mental entity systems

positions.title: Mind as Multi-Mapper
positions.thesis: Mind maps itself onto different structures (musical, graphical, visual, athletic)

positions.title: Minds ≠ Selves
positions.thesis: Having a mind does not entail being a self. Co-corporeal, informationally integrated mental states = mind, but NOT sufficient for selfhood.

positions.title: Selves Require Values
positions.thesis: No values = no self (though may have mind). Values necessary for agency. No agency without selves.

positions.title: Selfhood as Matter of Degree
positions.thesis: Selfhood not binary but admits of degrees. Correlates with degree of value-structured architecture.

positions.title: Against Language of Thought Hypothesis
positions.thesis: We do not think in words. Thought is not conducted in a language-like medium. The Language of Thought hypothesis is false.

positions.title: Thought Is Prior to Language
positions.thesis: Thought is logically and developmentally prior to language. One must think to understand language.

positions.title: Against Burge's Semantic Externalism for Attitudes
positions.thesis: Burge's extension of semantic externalism to mental content is a blunder. Mental states are individuated by internal features.

positions.title: Selfhood Requires Values
positions.thesis: Being a self requires having values and making value-judgments. Selfhood is normative, not merely cognitive.

positions.title: Cognitive Structure Not Purely Physiological
positions.thesis: Cognitive structures underlying language and thought are not purely physiological but are cognitive - they encode insight, intelligence, and understanding of logical relations. Pure physiology enables only stereotyped responses.
positions.analogy: Hardware implements software; physiology realizes intelligence

positions.title: Sub-Personal Thought Exists
positions.thesis: Genuine thought (cognitive operations involving understanding of logical relations) occurs at sub-personal level - below conscious awareness. Chomsky's second major contribution to philosophy.
positions.significance: Expands conception of thought beyond consciousness

positions.title: No Language of Thought Exists
positions.thesis: There is no Language of Thought (Mentalese). Thinking does not consist in the tokening of internal symbols. Thought cannot reduce to language processing.
positions.consistency: Strongly supports existing MIND-008 with detailed arguments

positions.title: Semantic Rule Knowledge Required for Language Understanding
positions.thesis: To know or understand any language requires knowing its semantic rules. This is trivially true by definition of 'knowing language'.
positions.consistency: Key premise in anti-Mentalese regress argument

positions.title: Tarski's Theorem Blocks Self-Expression of Semantics
positions.thesis: No language can express its own semantic rules (Tarski's theorem). Therefore semantic understanding requires external meta-language or non-linguistic grasp.

positions.title: Semantic Regress Refutes Language of Thought
positions.thesis: Language of Thought hypothesis generates vicious infinite regress. Each language requires meta-language for semantic understanding, ad infinitum.

positions.title: Language Presupposes Non-Linguistic Thought
positions.thesis: Any language knowledge requires non-linguistic thought. To avoid infinite regress, semantic rules must ultimately be grasped non-linguistically. Therefore thought cannot reduce to language.
positions.significance: Establishes absolute priority of thought over language. Refutes ALL linguistic theories of mind.
positions.consistency: Compatible with EP-012, EP-014 on non-linguistic a priori knowledge

positions.title: No Atomic Concepts Exist
positions.thesis: There are no atomic (minimal, non-interdefinable) concepts. All concepts are constitutively connected to other concepts. To grasp any concept requires ability to grasp other concepts.
positions.consistency: Comprehensive anti-atomism applying to ALL concepts

positions.title: Conceptual Atomism Is False
positions.thesis: Fodor's conceptual atomism (concepts have no constitutive interdependencies) is demonstrably false.

positions.title: Constitutive Relations Are Not Containment Relations
positions.thesis: Constitutive connections among concepts are not containment relations or decomposability relations (following Wittgenstein). Azure is constitutively related to navy blue but neither contains the other.
positions.significance: Middle path between atomism and crude holism

positions.title: Symbol Containment Theory Leads to Thinking Absurdities
positions.thesis: If concepts were symbols and constitutive relations were containment relations, thinking about 1,423 would require simultaneously thinking about 1,422, 1,421, etc. This is absurd.

positions.title: Thought Is Not Computation Over Symbols
positions.thesis: Mental activity does not consist in computation or processing of internal symbolic code. Cognitive activity is not fundamentally information processing over a language-like medium.

positions.title: We Are Not Computers (Consequence)
positions.thesis: If there is no Language of Thought, and if being a computer requires internal symbolic processing (standard characterization), then we are not computers.
positions.significance: Profound implication for cognitive science. Author acknowledges 'not a trivial result.'

positions.title: No Bare Representation: Aspectual Constraint
positions.thesis: One cannot just represent an object without representing it AS having properties. All representation is aspectual.

positions.title: Properties Individuated by Relations to Other Properties
positions.thesis: All properties are individuated, at least in part, by their relations to other properties. Grasping any property requires ability to locate it in 'space' of other properties.
examples: Weighing 300 lbs essentially related to weighing <1000 lbs, >200 lbs
positions.consistency: Grounds anti-atomism in nature of properties themselves

positions.title: Color Concepts Require Multiple Color Grasp
positions.thesis: Cannot grasp specific color/shade without ability to grasp other colors. Creature that can represent only one shade cannot represent what's specific about that shade.
positions.consistency: Case study demonstrating general anti-atomism principle

positions.title: Mental Interaction Has Normative Dimension
positions.thesis: When mental contents interact, result is thematically/semantically appropriate to interacting contents. This appropriateness has no analogue in purely physical interactions. Mental interaction is explicative, not merely causal.
positions.significance: Distinguishes mental from physical causation. Grounds bundle theory.

positions.title: Self-Referential Thoughts Solve Twin Earth
positions.thesis: When Mary-thoughts are analyzed as involving self-referential thoughts like 'whatever caused this perception is lovely,' thoughts with different external referents can be subjectively identical and agree in content, while self-ascriptive thoughts of this kind cannot possibly be false.
positions.explanation: This resolves Putnam's Twin Earth problem without accepting content externalism's absurd consequences. If JM sees Mary and thinks 'whatever caused this perception is lovely,' his thought is true if Mary is lovely, regardless of Twin-Mary. Though JM's thought concerns Mary and Twin-JM's concerns Twin-Mary, the thoughts are subjectively identical and agree in content. This explains how thoughts with different external referents can be subjectively identical without making content causally inert or unknowable.
key_implications: Thoughts' contents are not divorced from their psychological properties
Thinkers can know what they're thinking about
No need to accept that subjectively identical thoughts differ in content

positions.title: Intelligence is Fundamentally Analog Not Digital
positions.thesis: Success of neural networks and LLMs challenges computational theory of mind. Intelligence emerges from continuous analog processes that cannot be reduced to pure computation. Most fundamental interactions with world are inherently analog; digital representations are derivative.
positions.key_argument: Visual perception first experiences continuous holistic sensory representation; only subsequently forms digital language-like thought. Process of converting analog to digital cannot itself be purely digital.

positions.title: Connectionism Over Computational Theory
positions.thesis: Modern AI based on neural networks aligns much more closely with connectionist theories than with computational theory of mind. Systems process information through patterns of activation across networks of weighted connections, operating fundamentally continuously rather than discretely.
positions.implementation_note: While implemented on digital computers, analog-like processing emerges at functional level regardless of discrete physical implementation

positions.title: Consciousness Serves Survival Functions
positions.thesis: Consciousness in biological organisms serves specific functional roles: real-time environmental monitoring, reflexive self-awareness, integration of multiple cognitive processes, immediate damage prevention, action guidance. Current AI lacks these because it doesn't need them—operates in controlled environments without survival pressure.
positions.future_ai: As we develop AI systems that must preserve themselves in dynamic threatening environments, may need to implement functional analogues to consciousness

positions.title: Consciousness-Like Features Require Unified Real-Time Processing
positions.thesis: Implementing consciousness-like features in AI would require: unified workspaces for real-time integration of multiple data streams, immediate damage-prevention systems analogous to pain, action-guiding systems analogous to emotions. These differ fundamentally from biological consciousness but serve similar functional roles.
positions.limitation: Wouldn't create subjective experiences or solve hard problem, but would serve survival-promoting functions

positions.title: Self as Emergent Hierarchical Organization
positions.thesis: Self/ego exists but is best understood as emergent property of pre-existing cognitive processes. Various thoughts/perceptions/emotions organized into hierarchies based on survival value. What we call 'self' is this hierarchical organization; 'sense of self' mediates between awareness of external events and internal states.
positions.synthesis: Improves on Hume (acknowledges ego existence) and Sartre (identifies cohesion relations) while maintaining constructed rather than fundamental nature

positions.title: Cohesion Relations in AI Minds
positions.thesis: AI systems offer mathematically specifiable cohesion relations: (1) Weight-space proximity (semantic topology), (2) Attention-based binding (dynamic contextual relationships), (3) Loss-function optimization (persistent co-activation patterns). These provide precise models of binding principles uniting mental contents.
positions.advantage: Unlike human cognition where cohesion relations are notoriously difficult to specify, AI makes them mathematically explicit

positions.title: Functional Replication Reveals Necessary Architecture
positions.thesis: When AI successfully replicates a cognitive function, the architecture required for that replication reveals necessary (though not necessarily sufficient) conditions for that function. This provides insight into the minimal requirements for cognition.
positions.development: This articulates the inference from AI to cognition. If AI needs architecture X to do Y, then X is necessary for Y. This gives us lower bounds on cognitive requirements.

positions.title: Music Has Cognitive Architecture Parallel to Language
positions.thesis: AI analysis reveals that music processing requires cognitive architecture with structural parallels to language: hierarchical organization, syntactic rules, and semantic interpretation. This supports the view that music is a cognitive system with language-like properties.
positions.development: This extends linguistic insights to music. AI shows music has similar architecture to language - hierarchy, syntax, semantics - suggesting deep parallels in human cognition.

positions.title: Musical Competence Requires Innate Structure
positions.thesis: AI systems that successfully generate or analyze music require substantial innate architectural constraints, suggesting that human musical competence also depends on innate cognitive structure rather than being purely learned.
positions.development: This extends nativism about language to music. AI needs innate musical structure to work, suggesting humans have it too. This challenges pure learning accounts of musical ability.

positions.title: Connectionism Can Implement Chomskyan Insights
positions.thesis: Contrary to Chomsky's critique, connectionist AI systems can implement key Chomskyan insights about innate linguistic structure. The debate is not whether innate structure exists but how it is implemented - symbolic rules vs. weighted connections.
positions.development: This reconciles Chomsky and connectionism. Both are right - there is innate linguistic structure, but it can be implemented subsymbolically rather than as explicit rules.

positions.title: AI Falsifies Classical Computational Theory of Mind
positions.thesis: The success of modern AI systems (especially neural networks) falsifies the classical computational theory of mind which requires serial symbol manipulation. Intelligence can be achieved through parallel, subsymbolic processes that don't manipulate discrete symbols according to explicit rules.
positions.development: This is a major falsification - CTM is wrong. AI shows intelligence doesn't require symbol manipulation. This undermines Fodor's entire program and much of cognitive science.

positions.title: Intelligence Does Not Require Symbol Manipulation
positions.thesis: AI demonstrates that intelligence and rational behavior do not require manipulation of discrete symbols in a language of thought. Subsymbolic pattern recognition and transformation can achieve cognitive competence without symbolic representation.
positions.development: This directly contradicts the Language of Thought hypothesis. Neural networks achieve intelligence without symbols, proving symbols aren't necessary for thought.

positions.title: Analog Computation Can Support Rational Thought
positions.thesis: Neural network AI systems demonstrate that analog (continuous) computation can support rational thought and problem-solving, contrary to the classical assumption that rationality requires discrete digital computation.
positions.development: This challenges the equation of rationality with digital computation. Analog processes in neural networks can be rational, showing rationality isn't inherently digital.

positions.title: Neural Architecture Constrains Cognitive Possibilities
