positions.position: Compulsive work is about avoidance
There are two kinds of workaholics: those who love their work (not compulsive) and those who hate their work (compulsive)
The workaholic who hates his work is avoiding doing what he wants to do and must do it compulsively because he hates it
Stuttering is about not speaking with a single voice - two distinct currents of thought attempting to control speech
The degree of stuttering is proportional to how evenly matched the two thought-currents are; when one dominates, speech is normal
Men are self-contained and women are not - this is the fundamental difference between men and women
positions.source_section: How men and women are different

positions.position: Men who are not self-contained are not really men; women who are self-contained are not really women
positions.source_section: How men and women are different

positions.position: Spurning money is itself a way of wanting money - it is a reaction to the desire for money
The scholar who takes pride in poverty has the attitude of a jilted and petulant lover toward money
Overblown feelings are the opposite of what they are supposed to be
Emotions that are what they seem to be are not the objects of intense scrutiny by those who have them
Attitudes pressed into the service of tendentious narratives about oneself are the opposite of what they seem to be
Lack of physical coordination is accompanied by (since it is a manifestation of) lack of psychological coordination
Lack of coordination has to do with a failure to be centered
Being centered has to do with having an objective that one truly believes in
A psychological condition is pathological if and only if it restricts freedom
positions.source_section: Mental Illness: The Ultimate Litmus Test

positions.position: A psychological condition is positively counter-pathological if it augments freedom, even if it is unusual or unique
positions.source_section: Mental Illness: The Ultimate Litmus Test

positions.position: Writer's block only afflicts those who are not writing from the heart
Entrepreneur's block only afflicts those who are not working from the heart
When people choose a path because it is who they are, they succeed; when they choose because they have an agenda, they do not
The 'higher power' in AA is the alcoholic's own ego-ideal (superego), not an external deity
Surrendering to a higher power is really surrendering to a part of oneself, and at some level the alcoholic knows this
God is externalized conscience (externalized superego), not only in the alcoholic's case but in general
Religious sentiment involves projection of one's own ego-ideal/conscience as an external divine presence
Will must be distinguished from mere desire
Will represents values; mere desire represents urges
The alcoholic drinks because he desires to do so, not because he values doing so and therefore not because he wills to do so
In drinking, the alcoholic violates his values and therefore weakens his will
Will represents the dominion of one's values over one's behavior
When the alcoholic turns his will over to a higher power, he is reactivating his will, not deactivating it
The alcoholic has constructed an elaborate system of rationalizations to justify his degenerate behavior to himself
The alcoholic's rationalizations have undermined his ability to introspect
The alcoholic can no longer be aware of his values as internal entities and must consequently experience them as external entities (projection)
The alcoholic is internally divided - 'a real Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde'
Recovering from alcoholism involves becoming internally unified
The alcoholic's urge to drink is at odds with his values; surrendering to higher power realigns conduct with values, mending internal divisions
Insanity is about replacing reality with fantasy
Drinking is a way of turning away from reality; alcoholism is a compulsion to be insane
The use of alcohol mediates a temporary psychotic flight from reality
Psychotic delusions do more harm than good; psychotic people are extremely fragile
Religious sentiment (when healthy) is not sheer delusion; there must be non-delusions underlying the delusions, with delusions operating as foils
The atheist in the trenches finds not God but his own conscience; his pseudo-discovery of God is a cover for rediscovery of his conscience
Religious sentiment gives people the strength to do what they otherwise could not do
Religious sentiment cures people of otherwise incurable psychological maladies
A complete absence of religious sentiment is a mark of psychopathology
Religious sentiment involves awareness of a 'divine presence' experienced as a benevolent 'invisible order'
Those who completely lack religious sentiment tend to be internally divided; those who have it tend to be internally united
Acquiring religious sentiment (religious conversion) involves a 'surrender' of one's agency to some other power
Hypnosis and psychedelic drugs induce states similar to those that mediate religious conversions
There is no strictly medical cure for alcoholism
It is not possible to overcome alcoholism without having a religious conversion
Surrendering to higher power means giving it control of one's life and taking that control out of the hands of one's ego
Atonement is necessary to avoid relapsing; constant prayer helps prevent relapse
Mind-cure works by relaxing the barrier between the conscious and unconscious minds
Religious conversion involves relaxing the consciousness-unconsciousness barrier
Religious sentiment is highly dependent on unconscious ideation and associated mechanisms like displacement and projection
Derepressing emotion inevitably releases emotion into consciousness
The intensity of emotions in religious conversion is a consequence of emotions being released from the unconscious all at once
Religious sentiment embodies wishful thinking: the religious person believes not because data warrants it but because he wants to believe it
The religious person projects God rather than discovering him
Religious sentiment involves finding one's very own divinity to have a relationship with
The trench-atheist's deity happens to have the very moral code embodied in his conscience, indicating he is surrendering to his own morality
Religious people are more resilient and less fearful than non-religious people
Religious conversion involves a process of 'letting go' - deactivating one's ego and all of its defenses
Religious conversions involve intense emotions
In religious people, the unconscious and conscious minds communicate relatively freely
For those with religious mindset, the world is governed by a just and sapient presence
The incompletely unified moral and intellectual constitution is the psychological basis of the twice-born character
Without self-awareness, one tends not to adapt well, since adaptation requires revising and being aware of one's conduct
Self-awareness makes one self-critical and prone to forms of distress to which non-self-aware people are not prone
Optimism is a form of denial; one believes 'everything will be ok' when one has reason to believe otherwise but lacks self-confidence to confront that fact
Optimism is motivated by insecurity-driven lack of realism and leads to failure; self-belief is motivated by confidence-driven realism and leads to success
Attempting not to have thoughts of a certain kind tends to make such thoughts more likely to occur (Ironic Process Theory)

positions.title: AI Systems as Philosophical Evidence
positions.thesis: Operation of AI systems provides empirical evidence that can arbitrate between competing philosophical theories. How AI actually works reveals truths about reasoning, knowledge, language, mind.
positions.methodology: If theory predicts AI should work one way but AI works differently, provides evidence against theory

positions.title: Classical vs. AI Computing Architecture Alignment
positions.thesis: Classical logic's properties (explicit rules, step-by-step deduction, binary truth values, context-independence, compositional semantics) match classical computing architecture. System L's properties (flexible search, pattern-based reasoning, degrees of plausibility, context-sensitivity, holistic processing) align with AI systems.
positions.historical_insight: Transition from classical to AI-based logic marks fundamental shift in understanding nature and purpose of logical systems

positions.title: AI Vindicates Non-Revisionist Epistemology
positions.thesis: AI operation provides empirical support for non-revisionist epistemology that accepts knowledge about unobservables/future/counterfactuals, recognizes necessary integration of empirical and rational components, understands theoretical knowledge as based on causal mechanisms and continuity, rejects pure empiricism while maintaining importance of empirical evidence.

positions.title: AI Provides Empirical Test for Logical Theories
source: WORK-011 (Essay 1: AI Logic vs Classical Logic)
positions.thesis: Artificial intelligence systems, particularly large language models, provide empirical evidence about how reasoning actually works, revealing that System L's approach better captures both human and artificial reasoning than classical logic.
positions.development: This is the methodological core of the whole work - AI provides empirical tests for philosophical theories. Building working AI falsifies or vindicates philosophical claims about mind, language, and reasoning.

positions.title: Group Psychology is Explanatorily Prior to Individual Psychology
positions.thesis: Contrary to standard psychological methodology, group psychology should be understood as explanatorily fundamental, with individual psychology being derivative. Individual drives and behaviors are best explained as necessary for the survival and functioning of collectives, rather than collectives being aggregations of individual behaviors.
positions.explanation: This is the central thesis of the work and represents a methodological revolution in how to approach psychological explanation. Rather than explaining group behavior as an aggregate or diversion of individual drives, Kuczynski argues individual drives themselves exist because they serve collective functions. This reverses the standard explanatory direction.

positions.title: Conformism Cannot Be Explained by Individual Psychology Alone
positions.thesis: The extreme degree of conformism exhibited by people - their deference to convention, custom, and fleeting fads even at the expense of personal gratification - cannot be adequately explained by individual psychology even after accounting for intellectual shortcomings and fear of others.
positions.explanation: This is one of the key empirical observations supporting the thesis. The extent of human conformity goes beyond what individual-level explanations (self-interest, fear, ignorance) can account for, suggesting group-level explanatory frameworks are necessary.

positions.title: Collective Intelligence Exceeds Individual Intelligence
positions.thesis: Given how unintelligent, ignorant, and lacking in moral fiber most individuals are, yet how much intelligence, knowledge, and moral rigor is embodied in collective behaviors (corporations, academic disciplines), it is implausible that collectives are mere aggregations of individuals pursuing their own paths. The collective appears to be the primary thing biologically.
positions.explanation: This presents a puzzle that individual-first psychology cannot solve: how do collectively stupid individuals produce collectively intelligent institutions? The answer suggested is that collectives, not individuals, are the fundamental unit of analysis.

positions.title: Individual Consciousness as Illusion of Agency
positions.thesis: The appearance of individual choice and individualism per se may be largely illusory. What seems like individual agency may be better understood as individuals occupying specific roles within collectives that are biologically primary.
positions.explanation: This challenges fundamental assumptions about consciousness and agency. Rather than consciousness being the source of intentional action, conscious 'choices' may be epiphenomenal manifestations of collective-level processes. This has radical implications for philosophy of mind and free will debates.

positions.title: Individuals as Limiting Cases or Special Roles Within Collectives
positions.thesis: Bona fide individuals - people who genuinely think for themselves (geniuses) - can be understood as limiting cases of collectives (collectives of one), as rogue actors, or most likely as members of collectives who occupy unusual offices and are therefore wrongly seen as not being part of those collectives.
positions.explanation: This explains apparent counterexamples (autonomous thinkers, geniuses) within the collective-first framework. Even apparent individualists are better understood in terms of their relationship to collectives.

positions.title: Individual Drives Exist For Collective Functions
positions.thesis: The intense drives that individuals have to survive and experience gratification can be seen as necessary for, and therefore explainable in terms of, the collectives to which they belong. Individual psychology is what it needs to be for collective psychology to function.
positions.explanation: This provides the explanatory mechanism: individual drives aren't fundamental features that then create collectives; rather, individual drives are selected for and shaped by their role in enabling collective survival and flourishing.

positions.title: Cell Biology Analogy Supports Collective-First Methodology
positions.thesis: Just as individual cells are better understood in terms of their role in multicellular organisms rather than as autonomous individuals pursuing their own survival, individual humans are better understood in terms of their roles in human collectives. Cell-individualism can be explained in terms of cell-collectivism, but not vice versa; similarly for person-individualism and person-collectivism.
positions.explanation: This provides a biological analogy that both supports the main thesis and suggests it's a general principle of biological organization. The cell-organism relationship provides a model for understanding human individual-collective relationships.

positions.title: Collective Behavior Cannot Be Explained by Individualist Assumptions
positions.thesis: It is very difficult to explain group behavior - whether mobs or advanced cultures - on the assumption that collectives represent averages of behaviors of autonomous individual deciders. Outside of contexts with immediate physical threats or prospects of crude gratification, people give far too much weight to existing beliefs and mores in far too well-defined ways to be accounted for by individualist hypotheses.
positions.explanation: This articulates the methodological failure of individualist approaches. The patterns we observe in group behavior are too structured and too divorced from immediate individual interest to be explained as mere aggregations of individual choices. This necessitates collective-first explanatory frameworks.

positions.title: The State is Necessary for Contract Enforcement and Economies of Scale
positions.thesis: Contrary to anarchist positions like Goldman's, the state is necessary for enforcing contracts and enabling economies of scale, which are in turn necessary for the improvements to life that people actually want and value.
positions.source: Critique of Goldman, paragraph after Goldman's position
positions.explanation: This is Kuczynski's fundamental argument for why some form of state is necessary. Without state enforcement of contracts, modern economic life is impossible. This sets up his position that the question isn't whether to have a state, but what kind of state to have.

positions.title: Anarchism Fails on Pragmatic Grounds
positions.thesis: While Goldman may be right that the state causes some crime and often behaves unjustly, anarchism fails because without state enforcement of contracts and provision of public goods, people cannot achieve the standard of living and freedom they desire. The benefits of the state outweigh its costs.
positions.source: Critique of Goldman, final paragraph on Goldman
positions.explanation: This articulates Kuczynski's pragmatic critique of anarchism. He doesn't deny anarchist concerns about state injustice, but argues the alternative is worse. The critique is consequentialist rather than principled.

positions.title: Primitivism/Tribalism Fails on Pragmatic Grounds
positions.thesis: Rousseau's vision of pre-civilizational tribal life as ideal fails because tribal life involves serious disadvantages: lack of choices in profession and lifestyle, lack of medical care and education, geographical confinement, lack of technology, and need to work for every meal. These disadvantages outweigh any advantages of simpler social organization.
positions.source: Critique of Rousseau, paragraph beginning 'There is a serious problem'
positions.explanation: Kuczynski rejects romantic primitivism on pragmatic grounds. The disadvantages of pre-modern life are concrete and severe, while the claimed advantages (peace, simplicity) are both questionable and insufficient to justify the costs.

positions.title: Tribal Life Was Not Idyllic
positions.thesis: Contrary to Rousseau's romanticization, tribal life was likely not placid and carefree. Tribes attacked one another and were capable of behaving cruelly toward their own members. The evidence does not support the claim that pre-civilizational life was psychologically or morally superior.
positions.source: Critique of Rousseau, middle of critique paragraph
positions.explanation: This is an empirical challenge to Rousseau's idealization of primitive life. Kuczynski argues the historical and anthropological evidence contradicts the romantic picture.

positions.title: Revealed Preference Argument Against Primitivism
positions.thesis: If tribal life were truly idyllic as Rousseau claims, people today would opt for it, but they don't. This revealed preference is evidence against the claim that pre-civilizational life is superior.
positions.source: Critique of Rousseau, final sentence of critique
positions.explanation: This is an economic-style revealed preference argument. People's actual choices reveal their true values, and those choices consistently favor modern civilization over primitivist alternatives.

positions.title: Classical Liberalism is Probably Approximately Correct
positions.thesis: Hayek's liberalism - the position that good government is minimal government that protects people, gives them freedom, but otherwise doesn't interfere - is likely at least approximately correct. Over-regulated economies fail (Soviet Union) and minimally regulated ones flourish (early US), and people should be allowed to live as they want within reason.
positions.source: Defense of Hayek, paragraph beginning 'Is Hayek right'
positions.explanation: This is Kuczynski's positive political position. He tentatively endorses classical liberalism on both consequentialist grounds (it works better) and deontological grounds (people should be free). The qualifier 'approximately correct' suggests he's not fully committed but finds it the best available option.

positions.title: Competition is Superior to Central Planning
positions.thesis: Following Hayek, competition is superior to central planning not only because it's more efficient, but because it's the only method that doesn't require coercive or arbitrary intervention by authority. Competition allows individuals to decide for themselves whether the prospects of an occupation compensate for its disadvantages.
positions.source: Quote and endorsement of Hayek, middle section
positions.explanation: This articulates both efficiency and freedom-based arguments for market competition over planning. The key insight is that competition respects individual choice in a way that central planning cannot.

positions.title: Freedom Has Intrinsic Value Within Reasonable Limits
positions.thesis: People should, within reason, be allowed to live the way they want to live. Overly invasive governments prevent this and are therefore objectionable on that basis. The ability to choose one's own path in life has intrinsic value.
positions.source: Defense of Hayek, paragraph on whether Hayek is right
positions.explanation: This articulates a value commitment to personal freedom that underlies Kuczynski's political philosophy. Freedom isn't just instrumentally valuable (though it is that too), but has intrinsic worth. The 'within reason' qualifier suggests some limits but maintains freedom as a core value.

positions.title: Political Legitimacy Requires Both Effectiveness and Respect for Freedom
positions.thesis: A legitimate political system must satisfy both consequentialist criteria (it must actually work to improve people's lives) and deontological criteria (it must respect people's freedom and right to choose their own path). Systems that fail on either dimension are illegitimate.
positions.source: Implicit in overall structure of argument and conclusion
positions.explanation: This synthesizes Kuczynski's dual criteria for political evaluation. He rejects both anarchism (fails on effectiveness) and authoritarianism (fails on freedom), endorsing liberalism because it satisfies both. This suggests his ethical framework is neither purely consequentialist nor purely deontological.

positions.title: Conscious will as awareness of unconscious intention
positions.content: The conscious event W that a subject experiences as their decision to act is not the operative intention itself, but rather an awareness of an intention that has already been formed unconsciously. The readiness potential (RP) precedes W by approximately 350ms.
positions.context: In Libet's experiment, subjects report a conscious decision (W) to move their finger, but brain activity (readiness potential) begins 350ms before this conscious awareness. Kuczynski interprets this as showing that what we experience as 'deciding' is actually becoming aware of a decision already made unconsciously.
positions.implications: This challenges folk psychology's view of conscious decision-making and suggests consciousness plays a different role than we intuitively believe.

positions.title: W is not epiphenomenal despite lacking causal role
positions.content: Although W (conscious awareness of intention) is epiphenomenal with respect to the particular finger-movement in Libet's experiment, it is not epiphenomenal tout court. W has causal effects on subsequent intentions and behaviors.
positions.context: Kuczynski distinguishes between being epiphenomenal regarding one specific action vs. being causally impotent generally. W doesn't cause the immediate finger movement, but it does affect future decision-making.
positions.implications: This preserves some causal role for consciousness while accepting Libet's findings about the specific experimental action.

positions.title: Libet challenges compatibilism more than determinism
positions.content: The Libet experiment is more threatening to compatibilism than to traditional debates about determinism. The problem is not that choices are predetermined, but that what we experience as conscious decisions are 'on the sidelines'—not the operative causes at all.
positions.context: Compatibilists argue free will is compatible with determinism because we can act on our conscious desires/reasons. But Libet shows these conscious states aren't doing the causal work we thought. The real threat is to the idea that consciousness controls action, not to the idea that actions are determined.
positions.implications: This reframes the free will debate: the issue isn't determinism vs. indeterminism, but whether consciousness has the causal role compatibilists require.

positions.title: Libet's results more radical than Freud's unconscious
positions.content: Libet's findings are more radical than Freud's theory of the unconscious. Freud showed that some mental activity occurs unconsciously while treating consciousness as having real but limited power. Libet shows that even paradigmatic conscious decisions are not conscious decisions at all.
positions.context: Freud's unconscious explained neuroses and slips but preserved a domain of conscious control. Libet attacks conscious control at its core—in the very acts (like voluntary movements) we'd most confidently call conscious decisions.
positions.implications: Libet's challenge to folk psychology is more fundamental than Freud's, threatening the very idea of conscious agency.

positions.title: Consciousness integrates internal and external information
positions.content: One purpose of consciousness is to integrate real-time awareness of external events (sense-perceptions) with real-time awareness of internal processes (introspections). Consciousness pools these two datasets, though decisions are made unconsciously.
positions.context: Kuczynski proposes a functional model where consciousness serves as an information integrator, bringing together perceptual and proprioceptive data, even though the decision-making happens unconsciously.
positions.implications: This provides a positive account of consciousness's function that's compatible with Libet's findings.

positions.title: Conscious awareness serves approval/veto function
positions.content: W (conscious awareness) does not make decisions but rather approves or vetoes decisions already made unconsciously. Acts experienced as conscious decision-making are actually conscious acts of decision-approval. This approval extends to future similar intentions.
positions.context: Rather than consciousness initiating action, it monitors and can veto unconscious decisions. When we consciously 'decide' to move, we're actually approving an already-formed unconscious intention. This approval then influences future similar decisions.
positions.implications: This preserves a genuine role for consciousness (veto/approval) while accepting that it doesn't originate action.

positions.title: The illusion of free choice is functionally adaptive
positions.content: The experience of conscious decision-making as the source of our actions (when it's actually approval of unconscious decisions) is an adaptive illusion that prevents consciousness from being overburdened. The 'illusion of free choice' is a small price to pay for cognitive efficiency.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues the phenomenology of conscious decision-making is systematically misleading, but this misrepresentation serves an important function: it keeps consciousness from having to track all the complex unconscious processing that actually generates behavior.
positions.implications: This explains why the illusion persists and suggests it shouldn't be eliminated even if we intellectually recognize it as an illusion.

positions.title: Critique of 'phenomenological datum' argument for free will
positions.content: The argument that we 'just know' we have free will because it's a phenomenological datum is question-begging and misconceived. The cogito is analytically true (thinking requires a thinker), but free will is a form of causation, and causal relations are always open empirical questions.
positions.context: Some philosophers argue that free will is self-evident from introspection, analogous to Descartes' cogito. Kuczynski rejects this: unlike the cogito (which is conceptually necessary), free will involves causal claims about how consciousness produces behavior, and these are empirical questions that introspection cannot settle.
positions.implications: This undermines armchair philosophical defenses of free will that appeal to introspective certainty.

positions.title: Critique of 'Libet actions don't engage rationality' objection
positions.content: The objection that Libet's results don't generalize because they involve simple actions that fail to engage rationality is unsupported and likely false. First, there's no experimental data supporting this claim. Second, more deliberation makes it less likely that operative intentions are fully conscious.
positions.context: Critics claim Libet only studied simple finger movements, not complex rational deliberation. Kuczynski responds that (1) this is an empirical claim without supporting evidence, and (2) complex deliberation involves more unconscious processing, not less.
positions.implications: This defends the generalizability of Libet's findings to more complex decision-making.

positions.title: Philosophers' rejection of Libet uses inadequate standards
positions.content: Philosophers evaluating Libet's data employ standards of proof so stringent that by the same standards, there would be no reason to believe smoking causes cancer. By refusing to accept and model Libet's replicated findings, philosophers blind themselves to valuable information.
positions.context: Kuczynski criticizes the philosophical community's dismissal of Libet's work as methodologically unsound. He argues this reflects unreasonably high standards: if we demanded the same level of certainty for medical claims, we'd reject well-established causal relationships like smoking→cancer.
positions.implications: This suggests philosophers are being defensive rather than genuinely engaging with empirical challenges to their views.

positions.title: Standing intentions cannot be constituents of consciousness
positions.content: Standing intentions (e.g., intention to write a book over three years) are enduring structures like knowledge that 2+2=4. They cannot be constituents of consciousness because consciousness involves momentary events. One can be conscious of standing intentions, but they are not themselves conscious states.
positions.context: Kuczynski distinguishes occurrent mental states (momentary, conscious) from standing states (dispositional, enduring). Standing intentions are dispositional—they don't continuously occupy consciousness but can be brought to consciousness when relevant.
positions.implications: This clarifies the ontology of intentions and shows that not all mental states are conscious.

positions.title: Libet's findings likely extend to complex deliberative actions
positions.content: If intentions governing real-time actions (where consciousness is most heavily involved) are unconscious, it is doubly unlikely that intentions governing complex, deliberative actions are conscious. Complex intentions develop through protracted, largely unconscious thought-processes.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues from parity: if even simple voluntary movements (where we'd expect maximal conscious control) are unconsciously initiated, complex deliberative actions (involving more cognitive complexity) are even more likely to be unconsciously driven.
positions.implications: This extends Libet's findings beyond simple actions to undermine the idea of conscious control in rational deliberation.

positions.title: The 0.2 second delay is not mere tape-delay
positions.content: The 0.2 second delay between intention (RP onset) and conscious awareness (W) is not merely the minimum processing time required for awareness. Consciousness operates extremely quickly—sprinters can be conscious of individual steps and sub-components. The delay likely reflects W's functional role as action-monitor rather than action-instigator.
positions.context: Some defenders of conscious free will argue the 350ms delay is just how long it takes for neural signals to reach consciousness. Kuczynski counters that consciousness can track much faster events (as in athletic performance), suggesting the delay has functional significance rather than being a mere processing bottleneck.
positions.implications: This supports the monitoring/approval model over the idea that consciousness is just slow to register decisions it actually makes.

positions.title: God progressed to divinity from humanity
positions.content: Joseph Smith's King Follett Discourse argued that God was once a man who became divine through spiritual development. This represents a radical break from traditional Christian theology, implying divinity is not an absolute status but an achieved state, and the distinction between God and humanity is one of degree rather than kind.
positions.context: Smith's theology radically humanizes God while divinizing humanity. God achieved divinity through a process humans can also undergo. This is fundamentally opposed to orthodox Christianity which treats God as ontologically distinct from creation.
positions.implications: This dissolves the traditional absolute distinction between creator and created, suggesting a graduated metaphysical hierarchy.

positions.title: God created through organization, not ex nihilo
positions.content: God did not create the world ex nihilo but by organizing pre-existing chaotic matter. The Hebrew 'baurau' means to organize, not to create from nothing. Pure elements are eternal and indestructible—they can be organized and reorganized but never created or destroyed.
positions.context: Smith rejects creation ex nihilo based on Hebrew exegesis and metaphysical arguments. Matter is eternal; God's creative act involves imposing order on chaos rather than bringing being from non-being.
positions.implications: This shifts God's role from absolute creator to cosmic organizer, with significant implications for divine power and the problem of evil.

positions.title: Human spirits are immortal and have always existed
positions.content: The intelligence of human spirits has no beginning and no end. If something is immortal (has no end), logic dictates it also had no beginning. Therefore, human beings have always existed eternally. This eternal pre-existence follows from the same principle that makes God self-existent.
positions.context: Smith applies the logic of divine eternality to human spirits. Just as God has no beginning (being self-existent), human spirits also lack beginnings. This creates symmetry between divine and human eternal existence.
positions.implications: This makes human existence as fundamental as divine existence, radically elevating human ontological status.

positions.title: Multiple gods exist in hierarchical arrangement
positions.content: Although there is a supreme God, multiple lesser gods also exist. This follows from the doctrine of eternal progression: if humans can become gods through spiritual development, and this process has been ongoing eternally, then many gods must exist. The Hebrew 'Elohim' (Gods, plural) indicates this plurality.
positions.context: Smith's polytheism follows from eternal progression: if the process of humans becoming gods is eternal and ongoing, there must be many gods at various levels. The plurality in Hebrew scripture supports this reading.
positions.implications: This creates a graduated divine hierarchy rather than a monotheistic absolute, with implications for worship and theology.

positions.title: King Follett vision transcends its arguments
positions.content: Smith's arguments for his theological positions in KFD, even if assumed cogent, would not lead anyone to accept his radical vision. The merits of the vision lie in the vision itself, not in the arguments. This raises the historiographical question: where did Smith's vision originate?
positions.context: Kuczynski observes that Smith's exegetical and philosophical arguments are insufficient to generate his theological conclusions. The vision seems to come from elsewhere—either revelation, imagination, or other sources—with arguments serving post-hoc justificatory roles.
positions.implications: This suggests religious visions have sources independent of rational argument, raising questions about their epistemic status.

positions.title: Smith's theology evolved from monotheism to polytheism
positions.content: Joseph Smith's theology underwent systematic evolution. Early period (1820-1835): unambiguous monotheism. Middle period (1835): God and Jesus treated as distinct entities. Later Nauvoo period (1839-1844): full polytheism—God has a father, belongs to a council of gods, humans can become gods. Hebrew study accelerated the shift.
positions.context: Kuczynski traces Smith's theological development chronologically, showing a clear progression from conventional Christian monotheism to radical polytheism. Study of Hebrew and engagement with Old Testament plural forms (Elohim) seems to have catalyzed the later development.
positions.implications: This historiographical analysis suggests Smith's theology was dynamic and developmental rather than received whole in revelation.

positions.title: Orthodox Christianity is crypto-polytheistic
positions.content: Orthodox Christianity is not strictly monotheistic despite its claims. If Jesus is truly the son of God (not God himself), and the Holy Ghost is a distinct force, and God is an exalted person-like being, then there are at least three divine beings, making Christianity crypto-polytheistic. The doctrine that God, Jesus, and Holy Ghost are 'three but one' is absurd and logically incoherent.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues orthodox Trinitarianism is logically incoherent and amounts to covert polytheism. The formula 'three persons, one God' tries to have it both ways but fails to make sense. If the three are genuinely distinct (as 'persons' suggests), there are three gods; if they're not distinct, the Trinity collapses.
positions.implications: This suggests Smith's open polytheism is more intellectually honest than orthodox Christianity's covert polytheism disguised as monotheism.

positions.title: Christianity represents revival of polytheistic instincts
positions.content: Historically, polytheism is the rule and monotheism the exception. Christianity may represent a revival of polytheistic instincts. Early Church Doctors needed at least two divinities (God and Jesus) but couldn't openly embrace polytheism. They therefore affirmed absurdly that God and Jesus, though two, are one.
positions.context: Kuczynski speculates that Christianity's Trinitarian development reflects underlying polytheistic religious instincts reasserting themselves within a nominally monotheistic framework. The early church wanted multiple divine figures but inherited Jewish monotheism.
positions.implications: This provides a historical-psychological explanation for Christianity's awkward Trinitarian theology.

positions.title: Smith's theology prioritizes divine-human relationship
positions.content: Smith's fundamental question was: What must God be like if humans are to have the required relationship with Him? This breaks with both philosophical and Christian traditions that focus on logical puzzles about God's attributes. Smith starts with the assumption that God is psychologically able and willing to serve as guardian, attributing only as much power and knowledge as is compatible with this relational requirement.
positions.context: Kuczynski identifies a methodological shift in Smith's theology: rather than beginning with abstract divine attributes (omnipotence, omniscience) and deriving consequences, Smith begins with the desired divine-human relationship and infers what God must be like to enable that relationship.
positions.implications: This represents a pragmatic, anthropocentric approach to theology focused on religious practice rather than metaphysical speculation.

positions.title: Logical proofs of God turn Him into impersonal force
positions.content: Attempts to prove God's existence inevitably turn Him into an impersonal force or principle, stripping Him of the ability to have relationships with humans. If 'God' is defined as 'maximally perfect being,' 'guarantor of natural law,' or 'unmoved mover,' this abstracts away the personal characteristics necessary for divine-human relationship.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues there's a tension between philosophical theology (which tries to prove God's existence through abstract arguments) and religious practice (which requires a personal God). The more abstract the conception needed for logical proof, the less religiously adequate the resulting conception.
positions.implications: This suggests limits to philosophical theology and supports more pragmatic approaches to religious thought.

positions.title: Dodd-Frank's real problem is insufficient scope
positions.content: Criticisms of Dodd-Frank (reduced liquidity, expensive infrastructure, hurts small banks, government overreach) are either false or outweighed by countercriticisms. The real problem with Dodd-Frank is that it doesn't go far enough. It prevents certain predatory behaviors but does nothing to limit bank size, and therefore does nothing to prevent the systemic damage megabanks can cause.
positions.context: Kuczynski defends Dodd-Frank against standard conservative critiques but argues it's inadequate from the left: it regulates banking practices but doesn't address the fundamental problem of banks being 'too big to fail.' Size limits are needed, not just behavioral regulations.
positions.implications: This suggests the financial reform debate misses the crucial issue of scale and concentration.

positions.title: Low interest rates and excessive government debt create policy trap
positions.content: Thirty years of low interest rates (1990-2022) led to both inflation and massive government debt (140% debt-to-GDP). This creates a trap: raising rates to curb inflation makes servicing government debt prohibitively expensive, potentially forcing default; but lowering rates causes inflation to rise to unacceptable levels.
positions.context: Kuczynski identifies a structural economic dilemma: decades of cheap credit created unsustainable government debt levels. Now central banks face an impossible choice between inflation and default, with no good options.
positions.implications: This suggests current economic problems are structural rather than cyclical, requiring radical solutions.

positions.title: Megabanks cause market concentration and poor service
positions.content: The top 11 financial firms manage $46 trillion in a $125 trillion economy—massive market concentration. Moreover, megabanks provide worse service than smaller banks: fewer branches per capita, worse customer service, more fees. Their advantage is political, not economic: 'too big to fail' means they can take excessive risks knowing they'll be bailed out.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues against the standard efficiency defense of large banks. They don't provide better service; their dominance comes from implicit government guarantees that let them take risks smaller banks can't. This creates moral hazard and market distortion.
positions.implications: This challenges the idea that current financial structure reflects efficient market outcomes rather than regulatory capture.

positions.title: FIRE economy shifts from production to speculation
positions.content: The growth of the FIRE sector (Finance, Insurance, Real Estate) from 14% to 21% of GDP represents a shift from productive economic activity to rent-seeking, speculation, and wealth transfer. FIRE doesn't create wealth; it moves existing wealth around, extracting fees in the process. This represents a fundamental change in economic structure away from manufacturing and toward financialization.
positions.context: Kuczynski distinguishes wealth creation (making things, providing services) from wealth transfer (financial transactions, speculation, rent collection). The expansion of FIRE means a larger share of the economy consists of zero-sum or negative-sum activities rather than productive work.
positions.implications: This suggests a fundamental shift in capitalist economies toward parasitic rather than productive activities.

positions.title: 2008 crisis was dual: housing bubble plus banking collapse
positions.content: The 2008 financial crisis had two distinct components with different mechanisms: (1) a housing bubble driven by subprime lending and securitization, and (2) a banking system collapse caused by interconnected megabanks' exposure to toxic assets. These require different regulatory responses: the first needs better lending standards, the second needs to break up megabanks.
positions.context: Kuczynski distinguishes two analytically separate crises that happened simultaneously. The housing bubble was about bad lending practices; the systemic crisis was about bank size and interconnectedness. Conflating them leads to inadequate regulation.
positions.implications: This dual analysis suggests that addressing subprime lending (as Dodd-Frank primarily does) is insufficient without addressing bank size.

positions.title: Mental states divide into occurrent and dispositional
positions.content: Mental states fundamentally divide into occurrent states (momentary, present in consciousness) and dispositional states (enduring capacities or tendencies not continuously present). Beliefs, knowledge, standing intentions are dispositional; conscious thoughts, experiences, decision-awareness are occurrent.
positions.context: This ontological distinction clarifies debates about consciousness and mental states. Not all mental states are conscious; dispositional states exist as capacities that can be brought to consciousness but don't continuously occupy it.
positions.implications: This framework helps resolve confusions about what consciousness is and what mental states must be conscious.

positions.title: Consciousness as monitoring system rather than control system
positions.content: Rather than consciousness being the locus of decision-making and control (the traditional view), it functions primarily as a monitoring and approval system. Unconscious processes generate intentions; consciousness monitors these and can approve or veto them, extending this approval to future similar intentions.
positions.context: This inverts the folk psychological model where consciousness controls unconscious processes. Instead, consciousness monitors unconscious decision-making, with limited veto power. This explains both Libet's findings and consciousness's adaptive value.
positions.implications: This provides a functional model of consciousness compatible with neuroscience while preserving some causal role.

positions.title: Philosophers respond defensively to neuroscience challenges
positions.content: When faced with neuroscientific challenges to cherished philosophical positions (like free will), philosophers tend to respond defensively by dismissing the science, raising standards of proof to impossible levels, or claiming the empirical findings are irrelevant. This represents intellectual defensiveness rather than genuine engagement.
positions.context: Kuczynski criticizes the philosophical community's response to Libet as primarily defensive rather than constructive. Rather than engaging with the implications, philosophers find ways to dismiss the findings, suggesting their commitment to free will is pre-theoretical.
positions.implications: This suggests problematic insularity in philosophy and resistance to empirical constraints on theorizing.

positions.title: Religious thought prioritizes function over logical consistency
positions.content: Smith's theological method prioritizes the functional religious question (What must God be like for the right divine-human relationship?) over logical consistency and philosophical rigor. This represents a pragmatic rather than rationalistic approach to theology, where practical religious adequacy matters more than abstract coherence.
positions.context: Kuczynski identifies a methodological contrast: philosophical theology emphasizes logical proofs and consistency; Smith's practical theology emphasizes relationship and religious function. This explains why Smith's positions sometimes lack philosophical rigor but possess religious power.
positions.implications: This suggests limits to purely rationalistic approaches to religious questions and the value of pragmatic criteria.

positions.title: Polytheistic impulses may be psychologically basic
positions.content: The historical prevalence of polytheism and its apparent 'revival' in Christianity's Trinitarian development suggest polytheistic religious instincts may be more psychologically basic than monotheism. Humans may naturally tend toward recognizing multiple divine beings, with monotheism being the culturally constructed exception.
positions.context: Kuczynski speculates that polytheism's dominance across cultures and time periods, plus Christianity's struggle to maintain monotheism (resulting in the awkward Trinity), suggests psychological predisposition toward polytheism.
positions.implications: This suggests monotheism may be working against psychological grain, explaining its relative rarity and theological difficulties.

positions.title: Religious conceptions reflect relational needs
positions.content: Human conceptions of divinity are shaped by psychological needs for relationship, protection, and meaning. Smith's theology reflects this: God is conceived as having the attributes (limited power/knowledge, personal concern, accessibility) that enable the required guardian-child relationship, rather than attributes following from abstract philosophical reasoning.
positions.context: Kuczynski suggests Smith's theology is psychologically driven: God gets the attributes humans need Him to have for the desired relationship. This is more psychologically realistic than philosophical theology's abstract perfections.
positions.implications: This provides a psychological explanation for theological development and suggests anthropomorphism in theology may be inevitable.

positions.title: Eternal matter vs. creation ex nihilo
positions.content: There are two fundamentally different metaphysical pictures: (1) creation ex nihilo, where God creates being from non-being, making God absolutely primary and matter derivative; (2) eternal matter, where God organizes pre-existing matter, making God and matter coequal ultimates. These lead to radically different theologies.
positions.context: Kuczynski identifies this as a deep metaphysical fork in theology. Ex nihilo creation makes God utterly transcendent and all-powerful; eternal matter makes God more limited but also more relatable. Smith's choice of eternal matter has systematic implications for his theology.
positions.implications: This metaphysical choice cascades through theology, affecting divine power, the problem of evil, and the God-world relationship.

positions.title: Introspection cannot settle causal questions
positions.content: Introspection can reveal what mental states we're in but cannot reveal causal relations between mental states and behavior. Causal questions are empirical, requiring observation of patterns across cases, not introspective certainty. Therefore, introspection cannot establish that conscious will causes action.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues against the idea that we can know by introspection that our conscious decisions cause our actions. Introspection reveals phenomenology (what experiences we have) but not causal structure (how these experiences relate to behavior).
positions.implications: This limits the epistemic authority of introspection and opens folk psychological beliefs to empirical challenge.

positions.title: Philosophical resistance to neuroscience parallels historical science resistance
positions.content: Philosophers' resistance to neuroscientific findings about consciousness and free will parallels historical examples of disciplines resisting scientific findings that threatened their authority (e.g., Catholic Church vs. heliocentrism, vitalists vs. mechanistic biology). In each case, defensive reactions disguised as methodological sophistication protected cherished beliefs.
positions.context: Kuczynski draws a parallel between contemporary philosophy's resistance to neuroscience and historical examples of intellectual resistance to threatening scientific developments. The pattern is similar: raising impossibly high standards, claiming the science is irrelevant, or dismissing findings that challenge core commitments.
positions.implications: This suggests philosophers may be on the wrong side of scientific progress, defending positions that will eventually be abandoned.

positions.title: Action requires unconscious intention, not conscious decision
positions.content: Voluntary action requires an unconscious intention (which may or may not reach consciousness) rather than a conscious decision. The readiness potential represents this unconscious intention forming. Conscious awareness (W) is epiphenomenal regarding the particular action, though it may affect future actions through approval/veto.
positions.context: This redefines the necessary conditions for action. Traditional philosophy of action treats conscious decision as essential to voluntary action. Kuczynski argues the essential element is unconscious intention; consciousness is optional and, when present, has a different role than traditionally thought.
positions.implications: This requires reconceptualizing agency and responsibility if conscious decision isn't the source of action.

positions.title: Trinity doctrine is logically incoherent
positions.content: The orthodox Christian doctrine of the Trinity ('three persons, one God') is logically incoherent. If God, Jesus, and Holy Spirit are genuinely three distinct persons, there are three gods (polytheism). If they're not genuinely distinct, the Trinity collapses into modalism or unitarianism. No coherent interpretation makes them both three and one.
positions.context: Kuczynski applies basic logic to Trinitarian theology. The formula tries to have it both ways—real distinctness (three persons) and identity (one God)—but these are incompatible. Any attempt to explain away the contradiction either abandons distinctness or abandons unity.
positions.implications: This suggests Trinitarian theology is fundamentally confused and that Smith's honest polytheism is more logically defensible.

positions.title: Three Attitudes Toward Religion
positions.content: There are fundamentally three attitudes toward religion: (1) uncritical acceptance, (2) rejection, and (3) critical/reflective acceptance.
positions.context: Kuczynski identifies three basic stances one can take toward religion. Uncritical acceptance is the attitude of someone who doesn't know that non-religious views are possible (e.g., pre-modern tribesmen). Rejection is the attitude of those who examine religion scientifically and conclude it's false (e.g., Freud). Critical acceptance is the attitude of scholars like James, Otto, and Eliade who supplement scientific rationalism with firsthand knowledge of religious experience.
positions.implications: This tripartite division provides a framework for understanding different approaches to religious phenomena and suggests that neither naive acceptance nor simple rejection captures the full complexity of religious experience.

positions.title: Contemporary Fundamentalism is Reactive, Not Uncritical
positions.content: Contemporary religious fundamentalists are not genuinely 'uncritically accepting' of religion because they live in pluralistic societies and are reacting against non-religious views.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues that true uncritical acceptance of religion requires not even knowing that rejection is possible. Contemporary fundamentalists choose their fundamentalism in reaction to non-fundamentalist views. They have access to contrary perspectives through books, newspapers, and websites. By contrast, pre-civilizational tribesmen held spiritual beliefs naturally, not as a defensive reaction against alternative worldviews.
positions.implications: This suggests that contemporary fundamentalism is psychologically and epistemologically distinct from pre-modern religious belief, being more a form of ideology than genuine spiritualism.

positions.title: Contemporary Atheism as Herd Mentality
positions.content: Most contemporary atheists are simply following social norms rather than reasoning independently, making their mentality similar to medieval religious believers.
positions.context: Kuczynski distinguishes authentic rejectionism (e.g., Freud) from inauthentic rejectionism. Inauthentic rejectionists join atheist groups to fit in or gain prestige. Their beliefs are as dogmatic and emotionally-driven as medieval peasants' beliefs, even if the content is more reasonable. The brain centers mediating militant atheism are identical to those mediating religious fundamentalism.
positions.implications: This challenges the view that contemporary atheism represents rational progress, suggesting instead that for many it's merely a different form of conformity with similar psychological mechanisms as fundamentalism.

positions.title: Reductive vs. Non-Reductive Accounts of Religion
positions.content: There are both reductive (explanatory/causal) and non-reductive (phenomenological/essential) truths about religion, and the essence of religion lies in non-reductive truths.
positions.context: Kuczynski contrasts Freud's reductive approach (God represents father, religion mediates biological/social functions) with James' non-reductive approach. James doesn't deny reductive explanations but argues they're incomplete. Just as Newton's science can't be reduced to his psychological backstory, religious positions may need to be understood on their own terms even if they also admit of causal/functional explanations.
positions.implications: This suggests a methodological pluralism in studying religion where both causal-functional and phenomenological-essential approaches are necessary for complete understanding.

positions.title: Religion Requires Unshakable Conviction in Transcendence
positions.content: The essence of religious sentiment is the unshakable conviction that 'this world is not all that there is' and that psychological health requires this view.
positions.context: According to James, Otto, and Eliade's interpretation, religion essentially involves believing in something beyond the mundane world. They hold that psychologically healthy people, even self-identified agnostics and atheists, hold some variant of this view. Those who genuinely lack this view succumb to psychological morbidity.
positions.implications: This suggests that some form of belief in transcendence or 'something more' is psychologically necessary, which may be maintained even by those who explicitly reject religious labels.

positions.title: Writing as the Basis of Rationalism
positions.content: The development of writing is the foundation of rationalism, creating economies of scale and enabling the linearization of time.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues that rationalism emerges with writing. The written word enables large-scale social organization ('economies of scale') and transforms temporal consciousness from circular to linear. Religion in its institutionalized form represents an early stage of rationalism, not genuine pre-literate spiritualism.
positions.implications: This provides a materialist account of the emergence of rationalist thought, linking cognitive and social changes to technological developments in communication.

positions.title: Economies of Scale Cause Time-Linearization
positions.content: Large-scale economic and social organization causes the shift from circular to linear conceptions of time characteristic of rationalism.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues that as societies develop writing and create larger economic systems with 'economies of scale,' temporal consciousness shifts from the cyclical time of agricultural societies to the linear time of rational-bureaucratic societies. This transformation is fundamental to the emergence of rationalism.
positions.implications: This suggests that basic metaphysical and phenomenological categories (like temporal consciousness) have material-social bases and are not purely abstract or a priori.

positions.title: James, Otto, and Eliade Describe Animism, Not Institutional Religion
positions.content: When James, Otto, and Eliade discuss 'religion,' they are actually describing pre-civilizational animistic spiritualism, not institutional religions like Christianity or Islam.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues that James, Otto, and Eliade misuse the term 'religion.' They describe a mindset where one sees rocks as monster-hearts and trees as living beings—a pre-rational, animistic spiritualism. They are not describing Christianity, Islam, or other institutional religions, which are 'complex and internally consistent behavioral codes' that merely contain 'throwbacks to spiritualism.' Contemporary religious people like the Amish see the world in the same factual way as secularists.
positions.implications: This suggests that phenomenological analyses of 'religion' often conflate fundamentally different phenomena: pre-rational animism vs. rational ethical-legal systems with spiritual elements.

positions.title: Spiritualism vs. Rationalism as Fundamental Orientations
positions.content: For the spiritualist, the world is a living subject and partner; for the rationalist, the world is dead matter existing only to be used as an object.
positions.context: Kuczynski outlines the fundamental contrast. For rationalists: the world is moving parts, nothing is sacred/profane, morality is engineering, the world is impersonal dead matter, life is an anomaly. For spiritualists: the world is a subject, not merely useful but a partner, teeming with life, morality is emotional/empathic, organisms are more basic than dead matter.
positions.implications: This contrast suggests fundamentally different ways of relating to existence, with the rationalist adopting an instrumental stance and the spiritualist maintaining an I-Thou relationship with reality.

positions.title: Humans Cannot Become Non-Spiritual
positions.content: Just as we cannot become asexual (per Freud), we cannot become non-spiritual; we can only mistakenly believe we are non-spiritual and thereby undermine our biological condition.
positions.context: Kuczynski interprets James, Otto, and Eliade as arguing that spiritualism is ineradicable from human nature. The problem is not lack of spiritualism but false belief in its absence. When we wrongly think we're non-spiritual—perhaps because we mistakenly see rationalism as rejecting rather than extending spiritualism—we adopt lifestyles that contravene our spiritual natures.
positions.implications: This suggests spiritualism is a fundamental aspect of human psychology that persists even when denied, similar to how sexual drives persist even when repressed.

positions.title: Rationalism as Extension of Spiritualism, Not Rejection
positions.content: Rationalism is a 'rarefied extension' of spiritualism, not a rejection of it; the error is seeing rationalism as anti-spiritual.
positions.context: Kuczynski's interpretation suggests that rationalism develops from and extends spiritualist impulses rather than opposing them. The problem arises when we erroneously conceive rationalism as rejecting spiritualism. This misunderstanding leads to lifestyles that contravene our spiritual natures.
positions.implications: This dissolves the apparent conflict between scientific rationalism and spiritual orientation, suggesting they're stages in a developmental process rather than opposed alternatives.

positions.title: Contemporary 'Spiritualism' is Actually Nihilism
positions.content: 21st-century self-described 'spiritual but not religious' people manifest nihilism and absence of genuine spiritualism, not its presence.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues that modern 'spiritualism' (people who say they're 'spiritual but not religious') is in the same category as atheism—both manifest contemporary nihilism. Genuine spiritualism, as James, Otto, and Eliade describe it, involves seeing lightning as divine wrath naturally and immediately, not as a lifestyle choice or consumer identity. Contemporary spiritualism is self-conscious posturing rather than authentic spiritual experience.
positions.implications: This challenges the common view that 'spiritual but not religious' represents a viable third way, suggesting instead that it's merely another manifestation of modernity's spiritual emptiness.

positions.title: Supervenience Creates Circularity for PWSE
positions.content: The phenomenon of supervenience creates an insurmountable circularity problem for attempts to identify worlds with sets of propositions.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues that if a state description includes 'such-and-such micro-events are occurring,' it must also include 'so-and-so's heart is beating' (if the beating supervenes on those micro-events). But supervenience is standardly defined using worlds ('E supervenes on E* iff E occurs in any world where E* occurs') or necessity ('E supervenes on E* iff given E*, necessarily E'). Either definition makes it viciously circular to use supervenience to specify which sets of propositions count as worlds.
positions.implications: This shows that even sophisticated attempts to specify possible worlds using purely extensional criteria fail because they must covertly rely on modal notions.

positions.title: Non-Circular Supervenience Analysis Makes PWS Unnecessary
positions.content: If supervenience could be analyzed non-circularly without using modal concepts, then PWS would become unnecessary since we'd already have a non-modal analysis of modality.
positions.context: Kuczynski presents a dilemma: Either (1) defining supervenience uses modal concepts, in which case using it to specify worlds is circular, or (2) defining supervenience doesn't use modal concepts, in which case we've already analyzed modality non-modally and don't need PWS. This is a general pattern: any successful non-circular way of picking out the right sets of propositions would itself constitute an analysis of modality, making the appeal to worlds otiose.
positions.implications: This reveals a deep structural problem with PWS: either it's circular or it's unnecessary. Any move to escape circularity undermines the motivation for the theory.

positions.title: PWS Faces Unavoidable Dilemma - Circular or Superfluous
positions.content: PWS faces an inescapable dilemma: either it's viciously circular (using modal concepts to analyze modality) or it's superfluous (we already have a non-modal analysis making worlds unnecessary).
positions.context: Kuczynski generalizes the argument from MODAL-005. To avoid circularity, PWSE must find a non-modal way to identify which sets of propositions count as possible worlds. But possessing such a characterization would constitute a non-modal analysis of possibility (since we'd have a non-modal predicate satisfied by all and only possibly-true propositions). In that case, we no longer need to analyze modality in terms of worlds—we already have a direct analysis.
positions.implications: This suggests that PWS is fundamentally misguided as a project: modal concepts cannot be successfully reduced to or analyzed in terms of non-modal spatiotemporal concepts.

positions.title: Meta-Language Strategy Fails to Save PWS
positions.content: Relegating modal statements to a 'meta-language' does not eliminate vicious circularity problems for PWS.
positions.context: Advocates of PWSE try to avoid circularity by not allowing modal statements (which quantify over all worlds) to be members of worlds themselves—these go in the 'meta-language.' But Kuczynski shows this fails. Non-modal statements like 'Smith believes that possible worlds are not identical with members of U' can be members of worlds, yet these statements themselves quantify over the class of all worlds (U), creating the same circularity.
positions.implications: This closes off a major escape route for PWS, showing that standard logical techniques for avoiding circularity don't work in this context.

positions.title: Russell's Theory of Types Cannot Save PWS
positions.content: Attempts to avoid circularity by using Russell's Theory of Types (distinguishing 'orders' of propositions) fail in this context.
positions.context: One might try to resolve circularity by saying that when 'U' (the class of all worlds) appears in different contexts, it refers to different-order versions of the same set. Kuczynski shows this doesn't work because PWS requires that there be one determinate collection of all possible worlds. If we multiply this into different 'types,' we lose the determinacy required for modal analysis. Moreover, which 'level' of world contains ordinary propositions about Smith's beliefs becomes arbitrary.
positions.implications: This shows that sophisticated logical machinery developed to solve set-theoretic paradoxes cannot rescue PWS from its circularity problems.

positions.title: PWS Cannot Extensionalize Second-Order Properties
positions.content: PWS's identification of propositions with sets/functions forces it to deny that second-order properties (like necessity) are functions, which collapses the analysis of necessity.
positions.context: PWS identifies propositions with functions from worlds to truth-values (or with sets of worlds). If first-order properties were also functions, we'd falsely identify accidentally co-extensive properties. So PWS must deny that properties are functions. But then second-order properties (properties of properties, like necessity) also can't be functions. Yet PWS analyzes 'P is necessarily true' as P being assigned truth by function F (which assigns truth to all propositions true in every world). If necessity isn't a function, this analysis fails.
positions.implications: This shows that PWS's extensionalizing project is internally inconsistent: it requires treating some intensional entities (like necessity) as extensions while denying this for others (like properties).

positions.title: PWS Cannot Identify Intensional Entities with Extensions
positions.content: Propositions, properties, and other intensional entities cannot be identified with their extensions (sets, functions) without losing essential features like fine-grained individuation.
positions.context: PWS attempts to extensionalize intensional entities: propositions become sets of worlds, properties become functions or sets. But this fails to capture fine-grained distinctions. Necessarily equivalent propositions (like '2+2=4' and 'triangles have three sides') get identified despite being obviously distinct. Accidentally co-extensive properties (like 'renate' and 'cordate') get identified. The apparent elegance of extensionalization comes at the cost of fundamental distortions.
positions.implications: This suggests that intensional entities resist extensional analysis, requiring an intensional metaphysics and semantics.

positions.title: Inconsistency Without Explicit Contradiction
positions.content: Propositions can be mutually inconsistent without either being the negation of the other, undermining attempts to define consistency non-modally.
positions.context: Kuczynski points out (following later Wittgenstein) that 'x occurred at time t' is inconsistent with 'x occurred at time t*' (where t ≠ t*), yet neither is the negation of the other. Similarly, 'this surface is red' and 'this surface is green' are inconsistent without being negations. This means consistency cannot be understood purely as absence of (p & ~p) contradictions—it's an irreducibly modal notion involving what could jointly be true.
positions.implications: This shows that even basic logical notions like consistency are implicitly modal, making attempts to analyze modality in purely non-modal terms futile.

positions.title: Hintikka's Model Sets Presuppose Modality
positions.content: Hintikka's influential analysis of modality using model sets and state descriptions presupposes modal concepts and thus cannot provide a non-circular analysis of modality.
positions.context: Kuczynski examines Hintikka's system where necessity and possibility are defined relative to model systems (sets of state descriptions). A critical component is that some state descriptions are 'alternatives' to others (describing how the world might have gone differently). But the concept of being an 'alternative' is itself modal. Hintikka's system thus covertly uses modal notions to analyze modality.
positions.implications: Even sophisticated formal systems for modal logic, though valuable for many purposes, fail as analyses of the nature of modality itself.

positions.title: PWS Valuable as Statement, Not as Analysis
positions.content: Many contentions of PWS are correct and illuminating as statements about modality, but unacceptable as analyses of what modality consists in.
positions.context: Kuczynski emphasizes this crucial distinction throughout. It's truistic that 'P is possible iff P is true in some possible world.' As a statement, this is both correct and useful for systematizing modal reasoning. But as an analysis—an account of what possibility fundamentally is—it's circular (using 'possible world' to analyze 'possible'). PWS conflates statements with analyses.
positions.implications: This suggests we should value formal modal systems for their systematizing power while rejecting their pretensions to provide metaphysical analyses of modality's nature.

positions.title: Lewis's Counterpart Theory Faces Circularity
positions.content: David Lewis's counterpart theory, designed to solve problems for modal realism, either involves vicious circularity or makes modal claims depend on arbitrary resemblance relations.
positions.context: Lewis proposes that modal claims about an individual (like 'Socrates might have been a carpenter') should be understood in terms of counterparts—individuals in other worlds resembling Socrates. But: (1) If resemblance means 'sharing essential properties,' this is circular since essentiality is modal. (2) If resemblance means maximum similarity (without modal content), modal truths become arbitrary (which things happen to resemble Socrates most). (3) If counterpart is primitive, the connection to our modal intuitions is severed.
positions.implications: This suggests that even sophisticated versions of modal realism face deep problems connecting their technical apparatus to ordinary modal concepts.

positions.title: Essentiality of Origins Creates Problem for Counterpart Theory
positions.content: The plausible doctrine that origins are essential to individuals creates circularity for counterpart theory because identifying counterparts requires knowing essential properties, but identifying essential properties requires the counterpart relation.
positions.context: Kuczynski presents a vicious circle: If Socrates essentially has parents A and B, then Socrates' counterpart in another world must have as parents the counterparts of A and B. But who are A's and B's counterparts? Those whose parents are the counterparts of A's and B's parents. This regresses infinitely or circles viciously. The concept of counterpart is understood via essence (same origins), and essence is understood via counterpart.
positions.implications: This shows that combining counterpart theory with plausible essentialist doctrines (like Kripke's essentiality of origins) leads to incoherence.

positions.title: Counterpart as Primitive Makes Modal Claims Unintuitive
positions.content: If the counterpart relation is taken as primitive (not analyzable in terms of resemblance or essence), then modal claims become detached from our intuitions because they depend on brute facts about trans-world relations.
positions.context: Lewis acknowledges that one option is to treat 'x is Socrates' counterpart in W' as a primitive, unanalyzable fact. But then, as Lewis admits, counterpart theory loses its intuitive basis. If someone in another world whose life bears no resemblance to mine is nevertheless my 'counterpart,' it's unclear why that person's fortunes should validate modal claims about me.
positions.implications: This reveals a fundamental tension in modal realism: technical adequacy purchased at the cost of intuitive connection to ordinary modal thinking.

positions.title: Properties Have Counterfactual Content
positions.content: Following C.I. Lewis, practically all property attributions to spatiotemporal objects have counterfactual content, which creates deep problems for any attempt to analyze counterfactuals non-circularly.
positions.context: C.I. Lewis showed that classifying something as 'wet,' 'cold,' or 'solid' involves claims about its behavior under counterfactual circumstances (what would happen if you touched it, heated it, etc.). Since almost all properties used to describe spatiotemporal objects have this structure, and since counterpart theory needs to individuate things by their properties without circularity, counterpart theory faces insurmountable circularity problems.
positions.implications: This suggests that attempts to analyze modal and counterfactual notions in non-modal terms face a fundamental obstacle: the very concepts used in the analysis (properties of objects) are themselves modal.

positions.title: 'Innocent' Essential Property Analysis Makes PWS Unnecessary
positions.content: If there were a non-circular way of characterizing which properties are essential to individuals, counterpart theory would become unnecessary for modal analysis.
positions.context: Kuczynski presents another dilemma: If we could characterize essential properties without using modal concepts (an 'innocent' characterization), we wouldn't need worlds or counterparts to explicate modality—we'd already have a non-modal analysis. If we can't provide such a characterization, then using essence to define counterparts involves circularity. Either way, counterpart theory fails to achieve its goals.
positions.implications: This is another instance of the general pattern: PWS frameworks are either circular or unnecessary for modal analysis.

positions.title: Modal Realism Requires Retrograde Space-Time Conceptions
positions.content: David Lewis's PWS-based analysis of counterfactuals succeeds only if we accept philosophically retrograde conceptions of space and time.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues that Lewis's analysis requires treating spatial and temporal relations as fundamentally different from causal relations, which goes against modern physics and philosophy of science. The analysis also requires absolute space and time rather than relativistic space-time, making it scientifically dated.
positions.implications: This suggests that even if PWS worked formally, it would be unacceptable because it commits us to outdated metaphysical views about space and time.

positions.title: Counterfactuals and Causation Cannot Be Separated
positions.content: Counterfactual conditionals cannot be analyzed independently of causation; attempts to analyze causation in terms of counterfactuals (or vice versa) are circular.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues that Lewis's attempt to analyze counterfactuals in terms of similarity of worlds faces problems when trying to specify the relevant similarity metric. Causal structure seems essential to determining which worlds are 'closer,' but causation itself is often analyzed in terms of counterfactuals, creating circularity.
positions.implications: This suggests that counterfactuals and causation are conceptually interdependent, resisting reduction to more basic non-modal, non-causal notions.

positions.title: Similarity Metrics for Worlds Are Arbitrary Without Causation
