positions.content: Without invoking causal structure, any similarity metric used to compare possible worlds for counterfactual analysis becomes arbitrary and unintuitive.
positions.context: Lewis's counterfactual analysis says 'If P had been true, Q would have been true' means 'In the closest possible world where P is true, Q is true.' But which worlds count as 'closest'? Without building in causal structure, similarity judgments become arbitrary. But if we build in causation, we face circularity since causation itself is often analyzed counterfactually.
positions.implications: This reveals that PWS analyses of counterfactuals cannot avoid either arbitrariness or circularity in specifying the crucial similarity ordering.

positions.title: Modal Questions About Worlds Are Substantive
positions.content: Given truisms about spatiotemporal existence, it's a substantive modal question whether the worlds needed for PWS are even possible—a question PWS cannot answer without circularity.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues that we should ask: Are worlds containing light but not electromagnetic radiation possible? Are worlds with different natural laws possible? PWS claims these questions should be answered by checking whether such worlds are members of the space of possible worlds. But that's circular—we need to know if such worlds are possible to know if they're in the space of possible worlds. The modal status of alternative worlds must be resolved within some other modal framework.
positions.implications: This shows that PWS is 'parasitic on some more fundamental understanding of modality'—it presupposes rather than analyzes modal concepts.

positions.title: Modality as Internal Structural Properties
positions.content: A proposition's being necessarily true consists in its having certain internal structural properties; truth in all possible worlds is merely a symptom, not the essence, of necessity.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues (following Bealer 1998 and in his own work) that we know 'triangles have three sides' is necessary by examining how the proposition's components relate to each other—its internal structure. Being true in all worlds is a consequence of this internal structure, not what necessity consists in. This inverts PWS: worlds are useful for systematizing modal facts, but modality is more basic than worlds.
positions.implications: This suggests a return to a more traditional rationalist conception where necessity is grounded in conceptual/structural features rather than in modal space.

positions.title: Lewis's Recombination Principle Supports Structural View
positions.content: David Lewis's own account of modal epistemology (his 'principle of recombination') ironically supports the view that modality consists in structural properties rather than truth across worlds.
positions.context: Lewis says we discover whether P is necessary by employing a 'principle of recombination'—checking whether P's constituents are combined in certain ways. But Kuczynski points out that this means we know P's modal status by examining P's internal structure, and we can do this without 'leaving this world.' If P's structure is sufficient for knowing its modal status, why not analyze necessity in terms of that structure rather than in terms of other worlds?
positions.implications: This suggests that Lewis's own epistemology of modality undermines his metaphysics of modality, pointing toward a structural rather than world-based analysis.

positions.title: PWS Creates Set-Theoretic Paradoxes
positions.content: Identifying worlds with sets of propositions creates vicious circle problems analogous to classical set-theoretic paradoxes.
positions.context: When worlds are sets of propositions, and some propositions quantify over or refer to 'all worlds,' we get a member of a member of the set of all worlds quantifying over that very set. This is structurally similar to Russell's paradox and other set-theoretic contradictions involving self-reference.
positions.implications: This suggests that PWS faces not just technical difficulties but fundamental logical-mathematical problems that may be insurmountable.

positions.title: Pre-Civilizational Perception as Direct and Natural
positions.content: Pre-civilizational humans perceived agency and meaning in natural phenomena (lightning as divine wrath) directly and naturally, not through cultural interpretation or belief.
positions.context: Kuczynski contrasts genuine pre-civilizational spiritualism with contemporary religious belief. Stone age tribesmen saw lightning as divine wrath because 'this is how he naturally sees the world, not because he has been taught that this is how he should see the world.' This is direct perception, not interpreted belief. Modern religious people (like the Amish) 'see the world in the same way' as seculars—they see rocks as rocks, not as beating hearts.
positions.implications: This suggests fundamental differences in perceptual experience across historical-cultural contexts, challenging universalist accounts of perception.

positions.title: Modal Realism's Ontological Extravagance
positions.content: Modal realism requires accepting the concrete existence of infinitely many alternative universes, an ontological commitment many philosophers find unacceptably extravagant.
positions.context: If PWS requires literal worlds (MODAL-002), then we must believe that there actually exist concrete universes where Napoleon won at Waterloo, where dinosaurs still exist, where physics is different, etc. This multiplies entities beyond what most philosophers find acceptable (violating Occam's Razor dramatically).
positions.implications: This practical consequence of literal PWS leads many philosophers to seek alternative accounts of modality even if they can't identify specific logical flaws in modal realism.

positions.title: Essentialism and Modal Knowledge
positions.content: The doctrine that objects have essential properties (properties they must have to exist) creates special problems for modal analysis but may be unavoidable.
positions.context: Kuczynski discusses the plausible view (due to Kripke) that origins are essential: Socrates couldn't have had different parents. This essentialist doctrine is intuitive but creates problems for counterpart theory. More generally, essentialism suggests that modal facts about individuals depend on which of their properties are essential vs. accidental, requiring some account of this distinction.
positions.implications: This suggests that adequate modal metaphysics must incorporate essentialism but needs to explain essential properties without circular appeal to modal concepts.

positions.title: Space-Time Structure and Modality
positions.content: Questions about the structure of space-time (whether it's absolute or relational, whether space and time are unified) have implications for modal metaphysics.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues that Lewis's counterfactual analysis requires specific, controversial assumptions about space-time structure. If space-time is relativistic rather than Newtonian, if spatial relations are not fundamentally different from causal relations, then Lewis's analysis fails. This shows that modal metaphysics can't be developed independently of philosophy of physics.
positions.implications: This suggests that modal metaphysics must be continuous with scientific metaphysics, incorporating results from fundamental physics.

positions.title: Brain Centers for Militant Atheism and Fundamentalism Are Identical
positions.content: The brain structures that mediate militant atheism are the same as those mediating religious fundamentalism.
positions.context: Kuczynski claims that contemporary militant atheists and religious fundamentalists, despite having opposite beliefs, use the same neural circuitry. Both represent dogmatic, emotionally-driven responses rather than reasoned positions. This neurological fact supports the view that much contemporary 'rationalism' and 'irrationalism' are psychologically equivalent.
positions.implications: This suggests that the form of belief (dogmatic, tribal, emotional) may be more psychologically fundamental than its content (religious vs. secular).

positions.title: Denying Spiritualism Causes Psychological Morbidity
positions.content: According to James, Otto, and Eliade, genuinely lacking belief in transcendence (not merely lacking explicit religion) leads to various forms of psychological disorder.
positions.context: These thinkers hold that when people truly don't believe 'this world is not all there is,' they suffer psychological damage. Healthy atheists/agnostics actually hold variants of this transcendent view without recognizing it. The problem is not lacking institutional religion but lacking a sense of meaning beyond the mundane, which causes 'psychological morbidity.'
positions.implications: This suggests that certain forms of meaning-making or transcendent orientation are psychologically necessary, independent of explicit religious belief.

positions.title: Historical Variation in Fundamental Psychology
positions.content: Basic psychological structures (like perception and meaning-making) vary fundamentally across historical and cultural contexts, challenging universalist psychology.
positions.context: Kuczynski's account implies that pre-civilizational humans had fundamentally different perceptual and cognitive experiences from modern humans. They directly perceived agency in nature; we don't. This isn't just different beliefs with the same experiences—it's different experiences. This suggests that historical and cultural contexts shape basic psychology, not just explicit beliefs.
positions.implications: This challenges both evolutionary psychology (which emphasizes universal mechanisms) and phenomenology (which often treats experience structures as universal), suggesting deeper historical variation.

positions.title: Material Conditions Shape Consciousness
positions.content: Material developments (like writing and economic organization) fundamentally shape modes of consciousness, including temporal awareness and rationality.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues that writing creates rationalism, that economies of scale cause time-linearization, and that material social conditions determine basic categories of thought. This represents a materialist theory of consciousness where cognitive structures emerge from and reflect social-material conditions.
positions.implications: This suggests a broadly Marxist or materialist approach to consciousness and epistemology, where thought structures are not timeless but products of specific historical-material conditions.

positions.title: Natural Laws and Modal Space
positions.content: The relationship between natural laws and what's metaphysically possible is a substantive question that PWS presupposes rather than answers.
positions.context: Kuczynski asks: Are worlds with different laws of nature possible? Are worlds with light but not EM radiation possible? PWS should answer these by checking if such worlds are in modal space. But to construct modal space, we need to know which worlds are possible, which requires knowing if violations of natural law are possible. This is a substantive scientific-metaphysical question, not answerable within PWS.
positions.implications: This suggests that modal metaphysics cannot be developed a priori but must engage with philosophy of science and actual scientific theories about laws of nature.

positions.title: Levels of Analysis in Studying Phenomena
positions.content: Phenomena like religion admit of both reductive (causal-explanatory) and non-reductive (phenomenological-essential) analysis, both of which may provide genuine truths.
positions.context: Following James, Kuczynski recognizes that religion can be studied scientifically (explaining its causes and functions) and phenomenologically (describing its essential features). These are complementary rather than competing approaches. The reductive level explains why religion exists; the non-reductive level describes what it is. Both levels are legitimate and necessary.
positions.implications: This supports methodological pluralism in human sciences, rejecting both naive reductionism and anti-naturalist obscurantism.

positions.title: Statement vs. Analysis in Philosophy
positions.content: Many philosophical claims are valuable as true statements while failing as analyses; confusing these roles leads to philosophical errors.
positions.context: Kuczynski emphasizes throughout that 'P is possible iff P is true in some possible world' is a correct statement—even a truism—but fails as an analysis because it's circular. Good systematization (organizing our modal thinking using possible worlds) doesn't imply good analysis (explaining what possibility consists in). Much of modal logic succeeds as systematization while failing as metaphysical analysis.
positions.implications: This methodological distinction helps resolve debates in metaphysics and semantics by clarifying what different theoretical frameworks accomplish and where their limits lie.

positions.title: Limits of Conceptual Analysis
positions.content: Attempts to analyze all concepts in terms of more basic ones eventually fail; some concepts must be accepted as primitive and understood through their systematic interrelations.
positions.context: Kuczynski's arguments show that modal concepts can't be reduced to non-modal ones, that consistency presupposes modality, that semantic concepts can't be fully extensionalized. This suggests that the project of reductive conceptual analysis has limits. Some concepts are primitive, understood through their role in a system of concepts rather than through definition in more basic terms.
positions.implications: This suggests moving away from foundationalist approaches to concepts toward more holistic accounts where meaning is determined by systematic role rather than reductive definition.

positions.title: Theoretical Virtues and Theory Choice
positions.content: When choosing between theories, factors like ontological parsimony, intuitive plausibility, and coherence with science matter alongside formal adequacy.
positions.context: Kuczynski's critique of PWS goes beyond formal logical problems to include considerations of ontological extravagance (too many entities), counter-intuitiveness (modal realism violates common sense), and scientific adequacy (retrograde space-time conceptions). This implies that theory choice involves weighing multiple virtues, not just logical consistency.
positions.implications: This supports a pluralistic account of theoretical rationality where various considerations must be balanced rather than a single criterion (like logical consistency or empirical adequacy) being decisive.

positions.title: Role of Intuition in Modal Knowledge
positions.content: Modal intuitions (about what's possible/necessary) play a crucial but problematic role in modal epistemology and cannot be simply dismissed.
positions.context: Kuczynski appeals to intuitions about modal claims throughout. When counterpart theory makes modal truths depend on arbitrary facts, this counts as a problem because it's counterintuitive. But how should intuitions inform theory? If theories can't violate intuitions, science would be impossible. Yet theories completely detached from intuitions lose connection to what they're theorizing about.
positions.implications: This raises deep questions about the role of intuition in philosophy—how much revisionism is acceptable? When do counterintuitive consequences refute a theory vs. revealing surprising truths?

positions.title: Arbitrariness as Theoretical Vice
positions.content: When theoretical claims depend on arbitrary choices (with no principled basis), this is a serious theoretical defect even if the theory is formally consistent.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues that if which modal claims are true depends on arbitrary choices (like which similarity metric we use for comparing worlds, or which things we stipulate as counterparts), the theory fails even if it's formally adequate. Arbitrariness indicates that the theory isn't tracking objective features of reality but rather reflects our conventional choices.
positions.implications: This suggests that good theories must avoid arbitrary elements, providing principled bases for their claims—a constraint beyond mere consistency or empirical adequacy.

positions.title: Modal Knowledge via Structural Analysis
positions.content: We know modal truths by examining the internal structure of propositions—how their constituent concepts are arranged and related—not by surveying alternative worlds.
positions.context: Kuczynski argues that we know 'triangles have three sides' is necessary by analyzing the proposition itself—examining how the concepts 'triangle,' 'three,' and 'side' relate. We don't need to check all possible worlds. This suggests a rationalist epistemology where modal knowledge comes from conceptual analysis rather than empirical survey or stipulation.
positions.implications: This supports a return to rationalist epistemology for modal knowledge, contra empiricist approaches and contra the suggestion that modal knowledge requires metaphysically extravagant commitments.

positions.title: Conceptual Understanding as Basic
positions.content: Some forms of understanding (like grasping concepts and their relations) are basic and cannot be further analyzed or reduced to other cognitive processes.
positions.context: The structural account of modality and modal knowledge presupposes that we can grasp concepts and understand their internal relations. This understanding appears to be primitive—not analyzable in terms of more basic cognitive or computational processes. It's the foundation of rational thought rather than something requiring deeper explanation.
positions.implications: This challenges computational and empiricist theories of mind that try to explain all cognition in terms of more basic (computational, associative, sensory) processes, suggesting instead that conceptual understanding is sui generis.

positions.title: Tractatus vs. Later Wittgenstein on Contradiction
positions.content: Wittgenstein's early view (Tractatus) that all inconsistency reduces to explicit contradiction was questioned in his later work, which recognized irreducible forms of inconsistency.
positions.context: Kuczynski cites Wittgenstein's development. The Tractatus held that all inconsistency could be understood as presence of (p & ~p). But in Philosophical Remarks, Wittgenstein questioned this, noting that 'this is red' and 'this is green' (about the same surface) are inconsistent without either being the negation of the other. This recognition supports Kuczynski's critique of attempts to define consistency non-modally.
positions.implications: This shows that even a philosopher initially committed to a simple logical picture of inconsistency came to recognize its irreducible complexity, supporting Kuczynski's anti-reductionist arguments.

positions.title: Set-Theoretic Foundations and Paradoxes
positions.content: Attempts to use set theory as a foundation for semantics and modal metaphysics face fundamental paradoxes related to self-reference and circularity.
positions.context: Kuczynski shows that when worlds are identified with sets, standard set-theoretic paradoxes emerge in new forms. Members of worlds quantify over the space of all worlds, creating vicious circles. Standard solutions (like Russell's Theory of Types) don't work in this context because modal analysis requires a determinate, unified space of worlds rather than a hierarchy of types.
positions.implications: This suggests that set theory, despite its value in mathematics, may not provide an appropriate foundation for modal metaphysics and semantics, which require different conceptual resources.

positions.title: Conceptual Thought Cannot Be Fully Extensionalized
positions.content: The attempt to reduce intensional mental states and contents to extensional structures (sets, functions, physical states) systematically fails.
positions.context: PWS's extensionalizing project—treating propositions as sets of worlds, properties as functions—fails because it can't preserve the fine-grained distinctions essential to thought and meaning. Necessarily equivalent propositions that are obviously distinct get identified. This suggests that mental content has an irreducible intensional structure that resists extensional analysis.
positions.implications: This supports intentionalist theories in philosophy of mind and argues against computational/functional theories that try to identify mental states with formal/physical structures.

positions.title: Meaning cannot be reduced to observable consequences
positions.content: The pragmatist thesis (i) that 'the meaning of a hypothesis lies in its observable consequences' is false. The relationship between a hypothesis and its observable consequences is always contingent, never analytic, as it depends on what operative conditions and causal mechanisms obtain.
positions.context: Consider the hypothesis 'People come from apes'. Its observable consequences (fossil records, humanoid skeletons, etc.) are consequences only if certain conditions and mechanisms are operative. Different conditions would yield different observational consequences. Therefore, H and O (description of observable consequences) are not equivalent.
positions.implications: This undermines the pragmatist equation of meaning with empirical cash-value and shows that meaning transcends observational consequences.

positions.title: Truth is not identical with utility or power
positions.content: The pragmatist thesis (ii) that 'a true idea is one that allows us to control the world' conflates truth with knowledge. What pragmatism incorrectly represents as a virtue of truth itself should be correctly understood as a virtue of our knowledge of truth. It isn't truth that is empowering: it is knowledge.
positions.context: There are many truths, and they tend to add to one's power when they are known. But they are useless unless known—which shows that the property of being power-enhancing belongs not to those truths per se, but to our knowledge of them.
positions.implications: This shows that pragmatism systematically confuses properties of truth with properties of knowledge, committing a category error.

positions.title: Truth is not identical with assimilability
positions.content: The pragmatist thesis (iii) that 'true ideas are those we can assimilate, false ones are those we cannot' is false when taken literally. There are highly assimilable false ideas and highly non-assimilable true ones. Truth is not assimilability; rather, knowledge is assimilated truth.
positions.context: The pragmatist confuses the claim that truth is assimilability (false) with the true claim that knowledge is assimilated truth, and beliefs become increasingly knowledge-constitutive as they become increasingly grounded.
positions.implications: This reveals another instance of pragmatism confusing properties of truth per se with properties of our epistemic relation to truth.

positions.title: Truth is discovered, not made
positions.content: The pragmatist thesis (v) that 'truth is made, not discovered' is false. The negation (vN) 'truth is discovered, not made' is correct. Truth is objective—either there is an even number of stars in the galaxy or there isn't, independently of human construction.
positions.context: While (v) is clearly false, it parallels the true claim (v+) that 'knowledge is constructed through our active engagement with reality'. Pragmatism conflates the construction of knowledge with the constitution of truth itself.
positions.implications: This preserves the objectivity of truth while acknowledging the constructed, active nature of knowledge acquisition.

positions.title: Pragmatism is epistemology posing as metaphysics
positions.content: Each of the pragmatist theses (i)-(v) is a way of replacing an object-oriented conception of knowledge with a subject-oriented or agent-oriented conception. What pragmatism presents as claims about the nature of truth and reality are actually claims about knowledge-acquisition recast as metaphysical doctrines.
positions.context: The pragmatist theses (i)-(v) combat an 'intellectualist' conception of knowledge by replacing it with an 'interactionist' or 'operationalist' conception. However, they do this by conflating epistemological insights about knowledge with metaphysical claims about truth and being.
positions.implications: This diagnosis reveals the fundamental confusion in pragmatism: legitimate epistemological insights distorted into false metaphysical claims.

positions.title: Intellectual discoveries emerge from solving practical problems
positions.content: Intellectual discoveries are made by solving practical problems. Ventures are undertaken; roadblocks are hit; workarounds are created; and insights are the 'collateral damage' of these workarounds. Much of physics is fallout from attempts to create better weapons and dams, and much of mathematics is constructed to validate this fallout.
positions.context: Economics was invented as a way of managing the enormous influx into Europe of wealth from the New World. Anthropology was invented to help Europeans understand and interact more productively with natives. Psychoanalysis was developed to solve otherwise unsolvable psychiatric problems. Even 'purely philosophical' problems arise from practical needs—modern epistemology emerged when faith-based epistemology became untenable.
positions.implications: This supports a pragmatist insight about the practical origins of theoretical knowledge while not committing pragmatism's error of reducing truth to utility.

positions.title: Pure theory must be anchored in practical knowledge
positions.content: Once a discipline is launched, it can concern itself with 'purely theoretical' problems—problems relating to the mutual coherence of discoveries made in solving practical problems. But 'pure theory' tends to be stale and one-dimensional when it ceases to be anchored in practical knowledge. It degenerates into knowledge of empty formalisms when separated from practical applications.
positions.context: A personal anecdote illustrates this: studying finance academically produced only understanding of formalisms based on principles. Real understanding came only when those principles had to be relearned to solve practical problems. 'Theoretical knowledge' without practical grounding is merely schematic pseudo-understanding.
positions.implications: This validates pragmatist concerns about pure theory while maintaining that truth itself remains objective and not reducible to utility.

positions.title: Verification depends on observable consequences, but meaning does not
positions.content: The corrected pragmatist thesis (i+) holds that 'our knowledge of the veracity of a given hypothesis is based on its observable consequences.' This is true and truistic. But it must be distinguished from the false claim (i) that meaning itself consists in observable consequences.
positions.context: The observable consequences of a hypothesis are the vector sum both of what that hypothesis says about the world and of the subject's relationship to the alleged reality being described. Verification uses observable consequences, but meaning transcends them.
positions.implications: This salvages the kernel of truth in pragmatism's verificationism while rejecting its reduction of meaning to verification conditions.

positions.title: Knowledge is a subject-object relationship; truth is objective
positions.content: Truth is objective—it concerns facts about the world independent of knowers. But knowledge is a relationship between subject and object, between mind and world, and therefore has a subjective side. Speaking biologically, the intellect exists to help the organism survive and procreate, though in humans it has become partly autonomous.
positions.context: Interest in truth 'for its own sake' is not directly concerned with practical results, but is concerned with the cognitive basis of our ability to generate practical results. Pure mathematicians and philosophers investigate coherence-relations internal to datasets that are themselves of interest because of practical applications.
positions.implications: This reconciles the objectivity of truth with the pragmatist insight that knowledge has an essentially practical and agent-relative dimension.

positions.title: Classical epistemology wrongly treats knowledge-acquisition as passive observation
positions.content: Classical Epistemology (CE) holds that knowledge-acquisition is about taking note of what exists while doing as little as possible to change it, with action being merely a precursor to passive observation. This view is false or at least misleading. Knowledge acquisition fundamentally involves active engagement, not just passive reception.
positions.context: CE assumes that scientific action (excavating, vivisecting) is merely precursory to observation and not constitutive of knowledge acquisition. But this overlooks how action is integral to the knowing process itself, not merely a preliminary to passive observation.
positions.implications: This validates pragmatism's emphasis on the active, engaged nature of inquiry while not collapsing into pragmatism's errors about truth.

positions.title: No entity has both meaning and reference
positions.content: Reference is a property of spatio-temporal entities (expression tokens). Sense is a property of Platonic entities (expression types). No single entity possesses both properties. The Fregean picture of expressions having both sense and reference is confused.
positions.context: Kuczynski rejects the standard view that expressions like 'the inventor of bifocals' have both a meaning (sense) and a reference. Instead, types have sense (functions from contexts to entities), while tokens have reference (to the entities assigned by those functions).
positions.implications: This requires a fundamental rethinking of semantics, dissolving Frege's sense-reference distinction by distributing sense to types and reference to tokens.

positions.title: All meaningful expression-tokens refer
positions.content: On the correct conception of reference, all meaningful expression-tokens refer, including syncategorematic expressions like 'or', 'if', and case-markers. These refer to higher-order functions. The categorematic/syncategorematic distinction collapses given a proper understanding of reference.
positions.context: Contra the standard view that logical connectives and grammatical morphemes don't refer, Kuczynski argues they refer to higher-order functions. The meaning of an expression-token always coincides with its referent (on one disambiguation of 'reference').
positions.implications: This provides a unified semantic theory where all meaningful expressions are on par referentially, differing only in what they refer to (individuals vs. functions).

positions.title: Sentence-tokens refer to propositions (or proposition-involving functions)
positions.content: Sentence-tokens refer. Forceless sentence-tokens (those embedded in larger sentences without force) refer to propositions. Forced sentence-tokens (those with assertoric or other force) refer to functions involving propositions, not identical with propositions.
positions.context: In 'if Mozart wrote music, then somebody wrote music', the embedded occurrence of 'Mozart wrote music' is forceless and refers to a proposition. A free-standing assertion of 'Mozart wrote music' is forced and refers to a function involving that proposition.
positions.implications: This provides a unified account of sentential semantics distinguishing between forceless embedded uses and forced assertoric uses.

positions.title: Sentence-types have functions for meanings, not propositions
positions.content: Sentence-types do not have propositions for their meanings. All sentence-types uniformly have functions from contexts of utterance to propositions for their meanings. This holds even for seemingly non-indexical sentences like '2+2=4'—the uniformity of the class 'sentence' requires this.
positions.context: The sentence-type 'I am tired' obviously has a function (from contexts to propositions) for its meaning. But to avoid a massive cleavage in the category 'sentence', even eternal sentences like '2+2=4' should be analyzed as having functions for their type-meanings, though the function is constant.
positions.implications: This enforces a thoroughgoing two-dimensionalism about sentence semantics and preserves the unity of the syntactic category 'sentence'.

positions.title: Expression-types do not refer; only tokens refer
positions.content: Expression-types categorically cannot refer to anything. Even the expression-type 'Plato' doesn't refer to Plato; it has a constant function (from contexts to Plato) for its meaning. Only tokens of 'Plato' refer to Plato.
positions.context: Just as the type 'I' doesn't refer to anyone (its tokens refer to various speakers), and the type 'you' doesn't refer to anyone (its tokens refer to various addressees), so too 'Plato' as a type doesn't refer—only its tokens do.
positions.implications: This radicalizes the type-token distinction, making reference exclusively a property of concrete utterances, not abstract types.

positions.title: The Slingshot argument is unsound
positions.content: The Slingshot argument, which purports to show that sentences refer to truth-values, contains profound errors and proves things that are obviously false (e.g., that your car is identical with Mozart's favorite wig). The argument must be rejected by finding its errors rather than accepting its conclusions.
positions.context: Church's version assumes that replacing co-referring terms preserves meaning, but this leads to absurdity: if 'Scott' and 'the author of Waverley' co-refer, then 'Scott was wise' and 'The author of Waverley was wise' should mean the same thing, both meaning 'Scott is Scott'. But they clearly don't.
positions.implications: Rejecting the Slingshot removes the main argument for Frege's view that sentences refer to truth-values.

positions.title: Replacing co-referring terms cannot change meaning
positions.content: If two terms genuinely co-refer (refer to the same thing), then replacing one with the other cannot result in a change of meaning. What it means to say that terms co-refer just is that sentences differing only in those terms have the same meaning. All contexts are extensional at the level of literal meaning.
positions.context: The Slingshot assumes the principle (CR): 'Replacing expressions with co-referring expressions cannot result in a change of reference.' But it also assumes co-referring expressions can differ in meaning. These assumptions are inconsistent. If 'the author of Waverley' refers to Scott, then it just means Scott.
positions.implications: This vindicates thoroughgoing extensionalism: at the level of literal meaning, co-referring terms are intersubstitutable salva significatione.

positions.title: Sentences do not refer to truth-values
positions.content: Frege's thesis that sentences refer to truth-values is false. Sentence-tokens do refer, but not to truth-values. Forceless sentence-tokens refer to propositions; forced sentence-tokens refer to functions involving propositions.
positions.context: The Slingshot argument purports to prove that all true sentences refer to the same thing (the True) and all false sentences to the False. But the Slingshot is unsound, and the conclusion conflicts with any viable conception of reference.
positions.implications: This frees semantics from Frege's problematic equation of sentential reference with truth-value and allows a more natural propositional account.

positions.title: Apparent failures of extensionality explained by literal vs. communicated meaning
positions.content: Apparent counterexamples to extensionality (like belief contexts and modal contexts) result from confusing literal meaning with communicated meaning. 'John believes the inventor of bifocals snored' and 'John believes the first postmaster general snored' differ in what they communicate but coincide in literal meaning.
positions.context: When we define 'Hesperus' by description ('the first celestial body to appear in the evening sky'), we communicate information about Hesperus while the literal meaning is just about which object 'Hesperus' names. The communicated content differs from the literal content.
positions.implications: This preserves extensionality at the level of semantics proper while explaining apparent counterexamples as pragmatic phenomena.

positions.title: Externalism about content is problematic
positions.content: Semantic externalism—the view that mental content is individuated by factors external to the subject—faces serious problems. The work extensively critiques externalism and defends a more internalist conception of cognitive content.
positions.context: Chapters 18-23 systematically critique externalism, addressing issues of self-knowledge, the Jackson-Pettit program-explanation defense, the veil of perception problem, and the relationship between externalism and cognitive content. Volume II is dedicated to overturning externalist orthodoxies.
positions.implications: This challenges dominant orthodoxy in philosophy of mind and language, with ramifications for epistemology and psychological explanation.

positions.title: Externalism threatens self-knowledge
positions.content: If externalism is true—if mental content is individuated by external factors unknown to the subject—then subjects cannot have privileged access to their own thoughts. This conflicts with the apparent fact that we have immediate, authoritative knowledge of what we're thinking.
positions.context: Chapter 19 addresses 'Externalism and self-knowledge.' If what makes my thought about water rather than twin-water depends on my environmental history, and I can't distinguish those environments introspectively, then I can't know by introspection what I'm thinking about.
positions.implications: This is a major problem for externalism: it threatens to undermine first-person authority about one's own mental states.

positions.title: Frege's sense-reference distinction is confused
positions.content: The Fregean sense-reference distinction involves fundamental confusions. Sense should not be conceived as a mode of presentation possessed by referring expressions. Rather, sense is a property of types (functions from contexts to referents) and reference is a property of tokens.
positions.context: Chapter 9 is titled 'The confusions underlying the sense-reference distinction.' Rather than expressions having both sense and reference, the distinction should be understood as a type-token distinction: types have sense, tokens have reference.
positions.implications: This requires reconstructing Fregean semantic theory on a more coherent type-token foundation.

positions.title: Omniscience precludes action
positions.description: An all-knowing being cannot act because action presupposes ignorance. If one knows with certainty what will happen, one cannot coherently attempt to influence what will happen and therefore cannot intend to act.
positions.text_evidence: MASTER: NO. ACTION PRESUPPOSES IGNORANCE. IF YOU KNOW WITH CERTAINTY, WHAT IS GOING TO HAPPEN, YOU CANNOT COHERENTLY ATTEMPT TO INFLUENCE WHAT IS GOING TO HAPPEN AND YOU CAN THEREFORE CANNOT INTENT TO ACT.

positions.title: Omnipotence precludes feeling
positions.description: An all-powerful being cannot experience feelings. Only a being capable of being changed can experience feelings, and if a being is incapable of being changed, it cannot feel.
positions.text_evidence: MASTER: NO. ONLY A BEING THAT IS CAPABLE OF BEING CHANGED CAN EXPERIENCE FEELINGS. AND IF A BEING IS CAPABLE OF BEING CHANGED, THEN IT IS NOT CAPABLE OF FEELING.

positions.title: Immutability precludes self-change
positions.description: A being incapable of being changed cannot change itself. To change oneself is to be changed, albeit by oneself. A being that cannot be changed cannot be changed by anything, including itself.
positions.text_evidence: MASTER: NO, IT IS NOT. TO BE CHANGE ONESELF IS TO BE CHANGED, ALBEIT BY ONSELF. AND, OBVIOUSLY, A BEING THAT CANNOT BE CHANGED CANNOT BE CHANGED BY ANYTHING, INCLUDING ITSELF.

positions.title: Action requires self-change
positions.description: To act is to change oneself. A being that cannot change itself cannot act.
positions.text_evidence: MASTER: NO, IT CANNOT, SINCE TO ACT IS TO CHANGE ONESELF.

positions.title: Omnipotence entails impotence
positions.description: If a being is all-powerful (omnipotent), it is completely impotent. The concept of an all-powerful being is incoherent because such a being could neither act nor change.
positions.text_evidence: STUDENT: SO IF A BEING IS ALL-POWERFUL, IT IS COMPLETELY IMPOTENT. MASTER: CORRECT.

positions.title: Traditional divine attributes are incoherent
positions.description: The concepts of an all-knowing being and an all-powerful being are both incoherent. To the extent we conceptualize God as all-knowing and all-powerful, we are conceptualizing Him incoherently.
positions.text_evidence: MASTER: CORRECT. STUDENT: AND FOR SIMILAR REASONS, WE ARE ALSO TO CONCLUDE THAT THE CONCEPT OF AN ALL-KNOWING BEING IS INCOHERENT.

positions.title: The universe is counter-entropic through life
positions.description: While the physical universe is entropic (disintegrating according to thermodynamics), biological reality is counter-entropic - organisms grow and assume increasingly sophisticated energy-efficient forms. This counter-entropic tendency is even stronger at the psychological level.
positions.text_evidence: MASTER: TO THE EXTENT THAT THE WORLD FALLS WITHIN THE SCOPE OF THE DISCIPLINE OF PHSYICS, IT IS ENTROPIC... BUT NOTICE THAT, TO THE EXTENT THE WORLD FALLS WITHIN THE SCOPE OF BIOLOGY, IT IS COUNTER-ENTROPIC.

positions.title: Consciousness maximizes energy efficiency
positions.description: Mental/psychological dimensions make organisms more energy-efficient than they would otherwise be. Psychological growth is a particularly extreme way of increasing an organism's level of energy-efficiency.
positions.text_evidence: STUDENT: RIGHT. TO THE EXTENT THAT AN ORGANISM HAS A MENTAL DIMENSION, IT IS MORE ENERGY-EFFICIENT THAN IT WOULD OTHERWISE, PSYCHOLOGICAL GROWTH BEING A PARTICULARLY EXTREME WAY OF INCREASING AN ORGANISM'S LEVEL OF ENERGY-EFFICIENCY.

positions.title: Consciousness is inherent in existence itself
positions.description: It is inherent in existence that existence be conscious. The universe is disintegrating (lacking consciousness) only to the extent it is ceasing to be what it is. To the extent the universe is growing and becoming what it truly is, it has consciousness. Therefore, there is ipso facto a God - the universe itself, which is pulsating with life and thought rather than being cold and mechanical.
positions.text_evidence: MASTER: SO YOU SEE, MY SON, IT IS ONLY TO THE EXTENT THAT THE UNIVERSE IS DISINTEGRATING---THAT IT IS CEASING TO BE WHAT IT IS—THAT IT LACKS CONSCIOUSNESS; AND CONTRARIWISE, TO THE EXTENT THAT THE UNIVERSE IS GROWING—THAT IT IS BECOMING WHAT IT TRULY IS---IT HAS CONSCIOUSNESS.

positions.title: Logic as the study of formal truth
positions.description: Logic is the study of formal truth. A formal truth is a statement that holds entirely in virtue of its own structural properties, such as 'it is either raining or it isn't' or 'there are continuous functions that cannot be differentiated at any point.'
positions.text_evidence: Dr. K: It is the study of formal truth... A formal truth is a statement that holds entirely in virtue of its own structural properties.

positions.title: Mathematical logic studies statement-functions
positions.description: Mathematical logic is logic done with mathematical concepts and techniques. The central concept of mathematics is function (a rule assigning objects to objects). Mathematical logic studies statement-functions - functions that assign statements to statements - while other branches study numerical functions.
positions.text_evidence: Dr. K: Mathematical logic studies statement-functions. Most other branches of mathematics study numerical functions.

positions.title: Negation preserves incompatibility
positions.description: The negation of a statement is incompatible with that statement - they cannot simultaneously be true. To properly negate a statement, put 'it is not the case that' in front of it. The negation of 'someone is tall' is 'nobody is tall' (not 'someone is not tall'), since the latter can be true simultaneously with the former.
positions.text_evidence: Dr. K: The negation of a statement is incompatible with that statement... The negation of someone is tall is it is not the case that someone is tall; in other words, nobody is tall.

positions.title: Truth-functional operators defined by truth tables
positions.description: Conjunction, disjunction, and negation are truth-functional: whether the output sentence is true depends only on whether input sentences are true. 'P and Q' is true iff both P and Q are true. 'P or Q' is false iff both P and Q are false. 'Not-P' is true iff P is false.
positions.text_evidence: Dr. K: 'and', 'or', and 'not' are very special, since they are truth-functional, meaning that whether or not the output sentence is true depends only on whether or not input sentences are true.

positions.title: Non-truth-functional operators exist
positions.description: 'Because' and epistemic operators like 'Jim knows that' are non-truth-functional. Even if P and Q are both true, 'P because Q' isn't necessarily true. Similarly, given only that P is true, it doesn't follow that 'Jim knows that P' is true.
positions.text_evidence: MAX: Because even if P and Q are both true, 'P because Q' isn't necessarily true... Given only that P is true, it does not follow that 'Jim knows that Mary is in Alaska' is true.

positions.title: Recursive functions define logical systems
positions.description: Each logical function (negation, conjunction, disjunction) is defined for its own outputs - you can negate negations, conjoin conjunctions, etc., indefinitely. This means each function is recursive. A system of logic is a recursively defined statement class, and logic is the study of such classes. This is what it means to say logic is the study of formal truth.
positions.text_evidence: Dr. K: Notice that each of these functions if defined for its own outputs... this means that each of these functions is recursive... a system of logic is a recursively defined statement class. And logic is the study of such classes.

positions.title: All functions reduce to statement-functions
positions.description: While there are many types of functions (numerical, class-to-class, property-to-property), all functions are ultimately statement-functions, even though some appear not to be. This is a deep claim about the foundations of logic and mathematics.
positions.text_evidence: Dr. K: That all functions are statement-functions, even though some appear not to be. MAX: I don't understand. Dr. K: You will by the end of this podcast-series.

positions.title: Determinism defined as universal causation
positions.description: Determinism is the doctrine that nothing is uncaused. If determinism is correct, how the world is now determines exactly how it will be in the future, and how it was in the past determines exactly how it is now.
positions.text_evidence: Dr. K: Determinism is the doctrine that nothing is uncaused. MAX: So if determinism is correct, then how the world is now determines exactly how it will be in the future.

positions.title: Indeterminism entails some chaos
positions.description: If indeterminism is true, the universe is chaotic to a non-null degree. A single uncaused event makes indeterminism correct, regardless of how minute that event is or how orderly the rest of the universe.
positions.text_evidence: Dr. K: If there is a single uncaused event, then indeterminism is correct, even if the universe is otherwise completely deterministic. And it doesn't matter how minute that event is.

positions.title: Indeterminism threatens freedom more than determinism
positions.description: Indeterminism is more of a threat to freedom than determinism. Determinism is not a threat to freedom but is actually necessary for it. Indeterminism is as fatal to freedom as determinism is necessary for it.
positions.text_evidence: Dr. K: Indeterminism is more of a threat to freedom than determinism. In fact, determinism is not a threat to freedom. It is in fact necessary for it. Determinism is as necessary for freedom as indeterminism is fatal to freedom.

positions.title: External indeterminism doesn't increase freedom
positions.description: If the external world (outside our bodies) were indeterministic while our minds/bodies remained deterministic, we would not be more free. In a highly indeterministic world where baseballs might turn into hawks, we would have less control and thus less freedom.
positions.text_evidence: Dr. K: would we be more free in W than we are here? MAX: No; if anything, less free. At least in our world, there are dependable mechanisms. So we can control it. But in W, we can't even do that.

positions.title: Internal indeterminism doesn't increase freedom
positions.description: If our nervous systems were indeterministic, we wouldn't be more free. An indeterministic nervous system means current state fails to determine later states, so decisions don't reliably lead to actions. Knowledge at one time wouldn't reliably influence decisions later.
positions.text_evidence: Dr. K: So to the extent that your nervous system is indeterministic, its condition at time t leaves it open whether I will make the requisite bodily movements... Your berry-knowledge won't necessarily lead to the right decision unless the mechanisms that convert knowledge into intentions are intact.

positions.title: Mechanisms require determinism
positions.description: Where there are mechanisms, there is determinism. Where there is indeterminism, there are no mechanisms. A mechanism is something that can be relied on to produce an output of a certain kind when given an input of a certain kind. Mechanisms exist only to the extent the universe is deterministic.
positions.text_evidence: Dr. K: A mechanism is something that can be relied on to produce on output of a certain kind, when given an input of a certain kind... Where there are mechanisms, there is determinism. Where there is indeterminism, there are no mechanisms.

positions.title: Indeterministic minds are incoherent
positions.description: The more indeterministic a mind is, the more incoherent it is - its future states fail to cohere with present states, present with past. An indeterministic mind is no mind at all, but rather a series of mutually isolated minds, each existing only for an instant and therefore not existing at all.
positions.text_evidence: Dr. K: The more its future condition fails to cohere with its present condition... it is therefore no mind at all, but rather a series of mutually isolated minds... Since its earlier states fail to cohere with its later states... So it exists only for an instant. And therefore doesn't exist at all.

positions.title: Indeterminism prevents composite objects
positions.description: In an indeterministic universe, composite objects like billiard balls couldn't exist. The trillions of micro-particles would not be kept in place by deterministic laws and would go their own ways, causing the object to disintegrate or never form in the first place. Even atoms require deterministic laws among their parts to exist.
positions.text_evidence: Dr. K: To the naked eye, a billiard ball looks like a single indivisible object. But it consists of trillions of micro-particles interacting with each one another... if those interactions weren't governed by deterministic laws... each particle would go its own way... and the billiard ball would powder into nothingness.

positions.title: Freedom requires appropriate mental state responsiveness
positions.description: Inner freedom consists in one's current mental state embodying appropriate responsiveness to previous mental states, and future mental states embodying the right sort of responsiveness to present mental states. Freedom is about having a mind whose mental states determine one another in the right way, not about having undetermined mental states.
positions.text_evidence: Dr. K: So this inner freedom you are discussing---one has it to the extent that one's current mental state embodies the appropriate sort of responsiveness to one's previous mental states... possession of this inner freedom is not about having a mind whose mental states don't determine one another; it is about having a mind whose mental states determine one another in the right way.

positions.title: Freedom as causal integration
positions.description: A person is free if their mind is constitutive of the right sort of causal integration. Freedom requires both determinism (causal integrity) and the correct kind of causal structure, but determinism alone is not sufficient for freedom.
positions.text_evidence: Dr. K: Yes, a person is free if his mind is constitutive of the right sort of causal integration. MAX: And my view is that a person is not free unless his mind is constitutive of the right sort of causal integration, but I don't grant that a person is free if that condition is satisfied.

positions.title: Responsibility requires agent-constitutive causation
positions.description: For an action to be free is for the agent to be responsible for it. For an agent to be responsible is for agent-constitutive forces to be responsible for it, which means for them to cause it. Prior to the agent's existence, we cannot speak of the agent being made to do anything. Once in existence, being made to do something consists in agent-constitutive forces being directed contrary to the agent's objectives; doing something freely consists in those forces aligning with the agent's objectives.
positions.text_evidence: Dr. K: For an action on Stalin's part to be free is for Stalin to be responsible for it. And for Stalin to be responsible for it is for Stalin-constitutive forces to be responsible for it... And until such forces, such Stalin-constitutive forces, are in existence, we cannot talk of Stalin's being made to do this or that.

positions.title: Control over mind is prerequisite for freedom
positions.description: If a person does not have control over their future mental states, they do not have inner freedom. Someone who cannot govern their own mind is not free, similar to someone with a degenerative neural disorder who cannot govern their body. True freedom requires the ability to make judgments and decisions appropriately responsive to past experiences and controlled by logic and evidence.
positions.text_evidence: Dr. K: If a person does not have control over his future mental states, does he have this inner freedom you speak of? MAX: No. If a person cannot govern his own mind, he is not free.

positions.title: Power presupposes freedom
positions.description: There is a distinction between freedom and power. Power is the ability to convert freedom into desired results. Power presupposes the existence of freedom and must be distinguished from it. A rock has power (effects) but not freedom or the ability to do things in the relevant sense.
positions.text_evidence: Dr. K: There is freedom, and there is power. Power is the ability to convert freedom into desired results. But power presupposes the existence of freedom, and must therefore be distinguished from it.

positions.title: Counterfactuals as epistemic probability relations
positions.description: Counterfactuals are not statements about states of affairs in alternative worlds, but rather express relations of probabilification holding among statements. They register confirmation relations among propositions - the degree of credibility that certain propositions confer on other propositions. The factualist (possible worlds) analysis makes counterfactuals incoherent.
positions.text_evidence: Counterfactuals don't really say anything about events or anything concrete... Counterfactuals merely register confirmation relations among propositions.

positions.title: Factualist analysis of counterfactuals fails
positions.description: The factualist (possible worlds) analysis of counterfactuals is untenable. It requires metaphysically possible worlds with same laws but different facts, which is typically logically impossible. In deterministic worlds, any single event difference requires massive past differences. In indeterministic worlds, counterfactuals lose their truth conditions.
positions.text_evidence: The factualist view is not tenable... Two deterministic worlds cannot differ from each other with respect to a single state of affairs unless they differ with respect to a series of states of affairs extending back into the furthest recesses of time.

positions.title: Possible worlds analysis requires circular mixture of determinism
positions.description: The factualist analysis requires different counterfactuals to be validated by different mixtures of determinism and indeterminism. But all counterfactuals must be evaluated relative to the same world with the same laws. This requires our world to simultaneously exhibit incompatible mixtures of determinism and indeterminism, which is absurd.
positions.text_evidence: The factualist needs the world to be simultaneously characterized by different mixtures of determinism and indeterminism. But this is an incoherent requirement.

positions.title: Counterfactuals are crypto-probability propositions
positions.description: 'If A had been the case, then B would have been the case' means: The proposition K and A gives a high probability to B, where K is the conjunction of propositions we know to be true, minus the proposition that A and B were not the case.
positions.text_evidence: if A had been the case, then B would have been the case means: The proposition K and P(A) gives a high probability to P(B), where K is the conjunction of propositions we know to be true, minus the proposition that A and B were not the case.

positions.title: Probability is epistemic not metaphysical
positions.description: Probability is an epistemic, not a metaphysical, notion. Probability is a logical relation between propositions, not a property of states of affairs. When we say 'there is a 5% probability that Socrates had four kidneys,' we are saying something about epistemic possibility given our data, not about metaphysical possibility.
positions.text_evidence: It is clear, then, that probability is an epistemic, not a metaphysical, notion. Probability is a logical relation between propositions; it is not a property of states of affairs.

positions.title: False propositions probabilify other propositions
positions.description: False propositions probabilify other propositions just like true ones. 'The moon is made of cheese' is false, but it still gives very high probability to 'there is a piece of cheese that weighs more than 100 lbs.' 'Kennedy didn't die in '63' is false but still gives probability to other propositions.
positions.text_evidence: It must be kept in mind that false propositions probabilify other propositions just like true ones. The proposition the moon is made of cheese is false, but that doesn't stop it from giving a very high degree of probability (essentially 100%) to the proposition there is a piece of cheese that weighs more than 100 lbs.

positions.title: Laws cannot be defined except via counterfactuals
positions.description: There is widespread agreement that the concept of a law of nature cannot be defined except in terms of counterfactuals - a law is inter alia something that supports counterfactuals. This creates circularity for the factualist analysis, which must understand counterfactuals in terms of laws.
positions.text_evidence: the possible-worlds analysis of counterfactuals is guilty of covert circularity. For, thus analyzed, counterfactuals can only be understood in terms of laws of nature... But there is widespread agreement that the concept of a law cannot itself be defined except in terms of the notion of a counterfactual (a law is inter alia something that supports counterfactuals).

positions.title: Probability definable from actual events only
positions.description: The relevant kind of probability can be defined wholly in terms of what has happened (not what would happen and not even what must happen in a nomic sense). This avoids the circularity problem in analyzing counterfactuals.
positions.text_evidence: I also argue that the relevant kind of probability can be defined wholly in terms of what has happened (not what would happen and not even what must happen in a nomic sense). So my analysis isn't guilty of any kind of circularity.

positions.title: Indeterminism destroys counterfactual truth conditions
positions.description: If the macroscopic world is non-negligibly indeterministic, the factualist position is nullified. If identical initial conditions lead to an outcome only X% of the time, then the counterfactual 'if I'd turned the key, the car would have started' lacks truth value - at most we can say there's an X% chance it starts.
positions.text_evidence: if the macro-world here is indeterministic, then the factualist position is quite definitely false... The most one can say is: there is a 54% chance that it starts in w. Really, the proposition in w, under the circumstances described, the car starts seems to lack truth-value.

positions.title: Worlds are not sets of propositions
positions.description: Worlds are not sets of propositions. Our world is something which makes propositions be true or false. A set of propositions does not make propositions be true or false. The set <snow is white, grass is green, penguins fly> doesn't make any of those propositions true or false - it exists regardless of their truth values.
positions.text_evidence: Our world is not a set of propositions. Our world is something which makes sets of propositions be true or false. Any world deserving of the name is something which makes propositions be true or false. A set of propositions does not make propositions be true or false.

positions.title: Weak factualism is incoherent
positions.description: Weak factualists (who identify worlds with sets of propositions) hold an incoherent position. They deny that counterfactuals merely register probabilification relations among propositions, and they deny that counterfactuals register facts about other concrete worlds. But these are the only coherent options.
positions.text_evidence: the weak-factualist denies that counter-factuals merely register relations of probabilification (or entailment) among propositions. And he denies that counter-factuals register facts relating to other worlds (in any genuine sense of 'world'). So his position is completely incoherent.

positions.title: Maximal consistent sets useless for counterfactuals
positions.description: Alternative worlds as maximal consistent sets of propositions are absolutely useless for analyzing counterfactuals. Such sets would need to contain propositions covering every possible question, but including all such detail defeats the purpose of counterfactual analysis.
positions.text_evidence: alternative worlds, in the sense of maximal consistent sets of propositions, are absolutely useless for analyzing counter-factuals.

positions.title: Counterfactual truth independent of empirical discoveries
positions.description: The truth of counterfactuals is not contingent on empirical discoveries about the balance of determinism and indeterminism in nature. 'If Jones had struck the window, it would have shattered' doesn't become false if scientists discover unexpected mixtures of determinism. This shows factualist analysis is wrong.
positions.text_evidence: surely the truth of (4) is not contingent on the outcome of such inquiries. So the factualist has mis-analyzed (4).

positions.title: Discipline-relative counterfactual evaluation
positions.description: What a biologist considers counterfactually possible differs from what a physicist considers counterfactually possible because they relativize statements to different data sets within their disciplinary scopes. This may reduce to differences in what propositions are known by practitioners in different fields.
positions.text_evidence: What a biologist considers counterfactually possible differs from what a physicist would consider counterfactually possible... the physicist knows certain things that the biologist does not and that the economist knows certain things that the historian does not.

positions.title: Critique of Humean analysis of laws
positions.description: The Humean analysis of laws as regularities is viciously circular. If states of affairs are themselves causal processes (as they must be), then defining causation as regular concomitance of states of affairs is circular. Additionally, temporal succession itself appears to be a causal notion, making the analysis doubly circular.
positions.text_evidence: Hume says that laws are regularities involving certain kinds of states of affairs. But this presupposes that the notion of a state of affairs is a non-causal one. For obviously if states of affairs are themselves causal processes, then Hume's analysis becomes viciously circular.

positions.title: States of affairs are causal processes
positions.description: It is part of our concept of a state of affairs (excluding completely instantaneous ones) that such things are causal sequences. States of affairs cannot be understood as non-causal. This undermines Humean attempts to define causation in terms of regularities among states of affairs.
positions.text_evidence: It seems to me part of our concept of a state of affairs (leaving aside completely instantaneous ones) that such things are causal sequences.

positions.title: Temporal priority defined causally
positions.description: Temporal succession is itself a causal notion. A standard definition: x precedes y iff some possible (or actual) causal sequence connects x to y. Given that forces are deformations of space-time and no two events are totally causally isolated, x precedes y iff there is some causal process starting with x that ends with y.
positions.text_evidence: A standard definition of temporal priority is this: x precedes y iff some possible causal sequence (e.g., a beam of light) connects x to y... So it seems to me that x precedes y iff there is some causal process starting with x that ends with y.

positions.title: Obsessive beliefs are pseudo-beliefs
positions.description: Obsessive beliefs are pseudo-beliefs - if someone obsessionally believes that such and such, what they actually believe is the opposite. Obsessive hatred represents lingering attachment that won't be admitted. Obsessing that someone is listening to phone calls expresses fear that no one cares.
positions.text_evidence: Dr. K: if someone obsesses about his hatred of so and so, that is because he is not yet done with so and so. He is still attached to that person... if someone obsessionally believes that such and such, it is because what he actually believes is the opposite of such and such.

positions.title: Compulsive actions are pseudo-actions
positions.description: Compulsive acts are pseudo-actions - if one compulsively does such and such, one's real intention is to do the opposite. Compulsive avoidance of an ex-girlfriend indicates wanting to see her. Compulsive doting on mother actually expresses hatred for her.
positions.text_evidence: Dr. K: If one compulsively does such and such, it is because one's real intention is to do the opposite of such and such. If a given person compulsively avoids his ex-girlfriend, it is because he wants to see her.

positions.title: OCD essence is ambivalence
positions.description: The essence of OCD is ambivalence - simultaneously loving and hating the same object. The compulsively doting son both loves and hates his mother. Because he loves her, his desire not to be with her must express itself circuitously through compulsive behaviors.
positions.text_evidence: Dr. K: the essence of OCD is ambivalence. The compulsively doting son both loves and hates his mother. He loves her, and therefore feels obliged to have lunch with her on Sunday. But he also hates her.

positions.title: Doing and undoing in OCD
positions.description: The obsessional engages in 'doing and undoing' (Freud) - does something, then undoes it, then undoes the undoing. Driving to mother's house, then turning back for wallet, then back again for stove. This represents the stalemate between love and hatred, with each emotion expressing itself through the oscillating behavior.
positions.text_evidence: Dr. K: it is because of this emotional polarity within him that the obsessional engages in what Freud refers to as 'doing and undoing.' He does a given thing. Then he undoes it. And then undoes his undoing of it.

positions.title: OCD behavior as overdetermined
positions.description: OCD behaviors are overdetermined (Freud) - they serve multiple unconscious functions simultaneously. Back-and-forth driving serves both to express ambivalence toward mother and to discharge sexual frustration through piston-like repetitive motion mimicking the sexual act.
positions.text_evidence: MAX: So it is 'overdetermined', to use another expression of Freud's. Dr. K: Precisely... And it also has to do with his undischarged libido.

positions.title: Symbolic representation in OCD symptoms
positions.description: OCD symptoms involve symbolic representation of unconscious desires and conflicts. Fear about stove being left on represents undischarged libido; the stove symbolizes passionate desire. Driving behavior symbolizes sexual act. 'Fear' the stove will explode is really desire that genital region will 'explode.'
positions.text_evidence: Dr. K: The stove represents undischarged libido... What he wants is for the stove to explode. The stove represents his passionate desire for his girlfriend. His 'fear' the stove will explode is really his desire that he---meaning his genital region---will, so to speak, 'explode.'

positions.title: Intentions vs desires in action explanation
positions.description: There is a crucial distinction between desires and intentions in explaining action. Intentions are grounded in one's personality; desires need not be. There are free-floating desires that are 'in one, but not of one.' Counterfeit intentions exist where conscious intention differs from unconscious intention.
positions.text_evidence: Dr. K: Intentions are grounded one's personality. Desires need not be so grounded. There are free floating desires: desires that are in one, but not of one.

positions.title: Compulsive actions achieve opposite of conscious intention
positions.description: The end-result of a compulsively performed action is the opposite of the consciously intended result and coincides with the unconsciously intended result. Compulsive acts of kindness toward mother don't affect her like real kindness but like acts of hostility. Taking mother to endless doctors demoralizes her and weakens her immune system.
positions.text_evidence: Dr. K: the end-result of a compulsively performed action is the opposite of the consciously intended result---and therefore coincides with the unconsciously intended result... [Compulsive kindness] affects her in the same way as acts of hostility. For that is what they are.

positions.title: Authentic action requires alignment of values and desires
positions.description: Authentic actions must embody both values and desires in alignment. Actions driven by desire without values are instinctual reactions (real but not actions). Actions driven by values without desire are sublimations (actions but not real). Compulsive acts split into two half-actions - one all instinct, one all values - and thus aren't really anything.
positions.text_evidence: Dr. K: Actual actions must embody beliefs as well as desire. But also necessary that the values in question be in alignment with the desires in question... Desire-driven acts that do not embody values have the authenticity of veritable actions, but not the requisite sublimity, and value-driven acts that do not embody desire have the requisite sublimity of veritable actions... The former are real, but they aren't actions. The latter are actions, but they aren't real.

positions.title: Awareness without consciousness in the obsessional
positions.description: The obsessional is aware of underlying dynamics (mother's treachery, sexual frustration) without being consciously aware. One can be aware of something at the level of unconsciousness. The person doesn't quite see irritating behaviors for what they are even unconsciously, but is surely aware at some level.
positions.text_evidence: Dr. K: This young man obviously is not consciously aware of his mother's treachery. But he is aware of it. He probably does not quite see it for what it is, even at the level of unconsciousness. But he is surely aware of it.

positions.title: Single ultimate determinant despite overdetermination
positions.description: Despite overdetermination, behavior may have a single ultimate determinant. The son's behavior is overdetermined by both ambivalence toward mother and sexual frustration, but ultimately the sexual frustration is primary - ambivalence exists because mother causes sexual frustration. The two causes operate as a single cause in this context.
positions.text_evidence: MAX: ultimately, his behavior has only determinant, this being his sexual frustration... He is ambivalent towards his mother because she is causing him to be sexually frustrated. So his ambivalence and his sexual frustration are, at least in this context, operating as a single cause. Dr. K: Admirably well put, Max.

positions.title: Consciousness of hatred eliminates compulsions
positions.description: When unconscious hatred becomes conscious, associated compulsions vanish. The compulsiveness exists precisely because the true feelings are unconscious. Once awareness reaches consciousness, the need for disguised expression through compulsion disappears.
positions.text_evidence: MAX: What happens when it [unconscious hatred] becomes conscious? Dr. K: What happens is that any associated compulsions vanish.

positions.title: Compulsive behavior as leaking not acting
positions.description: In compulsive acts, the actor isn't truly acting - rather, sadism or hatred is 'leaking out' of them. Although compulsive acts discharge negative emotions, it isn't the person doing the discharging. The beneficent side is intentional but lacks emotional support, making it behavior one 'undergoes' rather than 'engages in.'
positions.text_evidence: MAX: even though those actions, for lack of a better word, do discharge Max's hatred of his mother, it isn't Max who is doing the discharging. It is rather that his sadism is leaking out of him... it almost fails to be his behavior. It is almost more appropriate to describe it as behavior that he undergoes than it is to describe it as behavior that he engages in.

positions.title: Deracinated values possess the agent
positions.description: When values are deracinated (lacking instinctual basis), it is less appropriate to describe them as values that the agent has than as values that have the agent. The agent is possessed by external value structures rather than authentically holding values integrated with their desires.
positions.text_evidence: Dr. K: given how deracinated his values are---how lacking in any instinctual basis---it is less appropriate to describe them as values that he has than it is to describe them as values that have him.

positions.title: Unconscious awareness distinct from conscious awareness
positions.description: There are levels of awareness: conscious awareness and unconscious awareness. One can be aware of something (like a mother's meddlesome behavior) without being consciously aware of it. This unconscious awareness is genuine awareness, though it may not involve seeing things fully for what they are.
positions.text_evidence: Dr. K: This young man obviously is not consciously aware of his mother's treachery. But he is aware of it.

positions.title: Compulsive time management as defense
positions.description: Compulsive punctuality (showing up two hours early) serves as a hedge against the unconscious wish not to show up at all. Being 'hyper on time' insulates against the desire to avoid the obligation entirely. This is another form of doing and undoing.
positions.text_evidence: MAX: He may be compulsively on time—hyper on time, as it were—as a way of insulating himself against his wish not to show up at all. Dr. K: Precisely.

positions.title: True agency requires ideals not just passion
positions.description: True agency is about fulfillment of ideals (not necessarily ethical, but ideals of some kind), not mere desire satisfaction. Where there is desire without values, there is passion (in both contemporary and etymological senses) but not action. An instinctual reaction driven purely by desire is not authentic action.
positions.text_evidence: Dr. K: True agency is about the fulfillment of ideals---not necessarily ethical ideals, but ideals of some kind or other---and where there are no values there are ipso facto no ideals... Where there is desire without values, there is passion---in both the contemporary and the etymological senses of the word---but not action.
